entries.name: Agent SDK bundle couples scaffolding command and verifiers
entries.description: The agent-sdk-dev plugin, `/new-sdk-app` command, and TypeScript/Python verifier agents operate together: Claude scaffolds a project then immediately runs the language-specific audits. This record ties the shared `agent-sdk` workflow together for future tuning.

entries.name: Agent SDK dev kit links scaffolding command with verifiers
entries.description: `plugins/agent-sdk-dev/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` advertises the toolkit, `commands/new-sdk-app.md` interviews the user before scaffolding, and the `agent-sdk-verifier-ts.md`/`agent-sdk-verifier-py.md` playbooks validate the resulting project. Claude combines them to spin up SDK apps and immediately audit TypeScript or Python integrations for compliance.

entries.name: Agent SDK new-app command drives interactive scaffolding
entries.description: `plugins/agent-sdk-dev/commands/new-sdk-app.md` walks Claude through setting up a fresh Agent SDK project by asking language, name, agent type, starter depth, and tooling, checking latest package versions, installing dependencies, scaffolding configs, verifying with the language-specific verifier agent, and handing back next steps and resources.

entries.name: Clean gone command removes stale branches and worktrees
entries.description: `plugins/commit-commands/commands/clean_gone.md` scripts a three-step cleanup: list branches to spot `[gone]`, enumerate worktrees, then run a bash loop that removes matching worktrees and force-deletes each stale branch. The prompt emphasises echoing progress so Claude reports which branches were purged or when nothing needed cleanup.

entries.name: Commit + push command enforces single-message git workflow
entries.description: `.claude/commands/commit-push-pr.md` restricts Claude to git/gh tool variants, surfaces git status, branch, and diff context, and instructs the agent to branch off main, create one commit, push, and call `gh pr create` in a single response. By forbidding any other output it keeps commit and PR sequences atomic and auditable.

entries.name: Commit command stages and records a single change set
entries.description: `plugins/commit-commands/commands/commit.md` confines Claude to `git status`, `git diff`, `git add`, and `git commit`, presenting recent log context before instructing the agent to stage and create one commit in a single response without extra narration. It is used when developers want Claude to package work without pushing or opening a PR.

entries.name: Commit workflow bundle keeps git commands aligned
entries.description: The marketplace bundle ships the commit, commit+push+PR, and clean-gone slash commands. Documenting the bundle shows how shared `git-workflow` guidance steers staging, pushing, and cleanup within Claude.

entries.name: Duplicate triage workflow pairs command with automation
entries.description: `.claude/commands/dedupe.md` coordinates with `auto-close-duplicates.ts`, `backfill-duplicate-comments.ts`, and the `lock-closed-issues.yml` workflow so that Claude can hunt duplicates, leave countdown comments, and ensure closed threads eventually lock. The orchestration keeps dedupe decisions, retro sweeps, and lock enforcement in sync.

entries.name: Feature dev bundle connects command to explorer, architect, reviewer
entries.description: The feature development ritual relies on `feature-dev.md`, the feature-dev plugin manifest, and the explorer/architect/reviewer agents. This overview highlights how discovery, architecture planning, and quality review stay synchronized via shared `feature-dev` tags before implementation starts.

entries.name: Feature dev command enforces seven-phase delivery ritual
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/commands/feature-dev.md` directs Claude to ask for language, project name, agent type, starting point, and tooling preferences before planning. It mandates reviewing official docs, decomposing work into discovery, exploration, clarifying questions, architecture, implementation, quality review, and summary phases, and requires using the matching explorer, architect, and reviewer agents plus verifiers before shipping.

entries.name: Feature dev plugin coordinates command and trio of agents
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` bundles the workflow, `commands/feature-dev.md` enforces the seven-phase ritual, and the `code-architect.md`, `code-explorer.md`, and `code-reviewer.md` agents cover discovery, architecture, and quality gates. The set gives Claude a structured hand-off from analysis to implementation planning before any edits ship.

entries.name: Issue dedupe command orchestrates multi-agent triage
entries.description: `.claude/commands/dedupe.md` whitelists only `gh` subcommands and scripts a five-step routine: confirm the issue still needs dedupe, summarize it, fan out five search agents with varied queries, filter false positives, then post up to three duplicate links with the standard countdown template. That enforced checklist keeps duplicate triage consistent and traceable.

entries.name: PR review bundle links command, plugin, and agents
entries.description: `/pr-review` work orchestrates `review-pr.md` with the PR review toolkit plugin and its suite of agents (code reviewer, comment analyzer, test analyzer, silent failure hunter, type design analyzer, code simplifier). The shared `pr-review` tag links command, plugin manifest, and agent playbooks to describe the end-to-end checklist for pull request quality gates.

entries.name: PR review toolkit syncs command with specialist agents
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` exposes the bundle, `commands/review-pr.md` choreographs scope detection and summary output, while agents like `code-reviewer.md` and `pr-test-analyzer.md` deliver focused analyses. Together they let Claude launch one slash command that fans out to comment, tests, error, type, and simplifier reviewers with a unified action plan.

entries.name: Review PR command coordinates specialized review agents
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/commands/review-pr.md` explains how to scope reviews from git diff, map PR changes to aspects, optionally filter by arguments, launch comment, test, error, type, code, and simplify agents sequentially or in parallel, then aggregate findings into critical issues, important issues, suggestions, and strengths with an action plan.

entries.name: Commit+push+PR command stays identical across CLI and plugin
entries.description: `.claude/commands/commit-push-pr.md` and `plugins/commit-commands/commands/commit-push-pr.md` share the same five-step checklist and context preload, keeping slash command and marketplace command behaviours perfectly aligned.

entries.name: New SDK app command grounds itself in official docs
entries.description: The command forces Claude to WebFetch the SDK overview plus the TypeScript or Python reference (and related guides on streaming, permissions, MCP, subagents, sessions) before proposing a plan, ensuring advice mirrors the latest documentation.

entries.name: New SDK app command enforces one-at-a-time requirement interview
entries.description: `new-sdk-app.md` orders Claude to ask language, project name, agent type, starting point, and tooling preference sequentially, waiting for each reply before moving on so setup stays conversational and accurate.

entries.name: New SDK app command double-checks package versions
entries.description: Before installing dependencies the script tells Claude to confirm the latest releases via WebSearch and to report the installed version afterwards, preventing tutorials from pinning stale SDK builds.

entries.name: New SDK app plan scaffolds scripts, configs, and env samples
entries.description: The Setup Plan section has Claude create the project directory, initialise package manager files, add tsconfig or requirements, install the SDK, generate starter code, produce `.env.example` plus `.gitignore`, and optionally lay out a `.claude/` directory so the user lands with a runnable template.

entries.name: Review PR command ships a Markdown action plan template
entries.description: `review-pr.md` includes the exact Markdown skeleton (Critical Issues, Important Issues, Suggestions, Strengths, Recommended Action) Claude should paste back so reviewers get a consistent checklist of fixes.

entries.name: Review PR command supports aspect arguments and parallel mode
entries.description: The command lists aspect keywords (`comments`, `tests`, `errors`, `types`, `code`, `simplify`, `all`) and notes that passing `parallel` launches agents concurrently, giving operators fine-grained control over review scope and speed.

entries.name: New SDK app command hands off to language-specific verifiers
entries.description: The Verification section tells Claude to launch `agent-sdk-verifier-ts` for TypeScript projects or `agent-sdk-verifier-py` for Python, review the PASS/PASS WITH WARNINGS/FAIL report, and fix findings before declaring the scaffold complete.

entries.name: Clean gone command reports when no cleanup is needed
entries.description: `clean_gone.md` asks Claude to explicitly say when no branches are marked `[gone]`, so operators know the cleanup loop didnâ€™t silently skip work.

entries.name: Agent SDK verifiers enforce TS/Python integration readiness
entries.description: The agent-sdk-dev plugin provides TypeScript and Python verifiers that audit SDK integrations after scaffolding. Documenting them together shows how the shared `agent-sdk` workflow maintains parity across languages.

entries.name: Code simplifier agent polishes recent changes without regressions
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/code-simplifier.md` directs the agent to refine only recently touched code by applying CLAUDE.md standards such as explicit function declarations, ES module imports, explicit return types, and avoiding nested ternaries while preserving behaviour and documenting significant refinements.

entries.name: Comment analyzer agent prevents documentation rot
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/comment-analyzer.md` teaches the agent to cross-check comments against code, assess completeness, flag misleading or redundant notes, and suggest removals or rewrites, structuring findings into critical issues, improvements, removals, and positives to keep docs trustworthy.

entries.name: Feature dev architect agent delivers decisive blueprints
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/agents/code-architect.md` frames the agent as a senior architect who mines CLAUDE.md and existing patterns, chooses a single approach, and produces an implementation blueprint detailing components, file changes, data flow, build sequence, and critical risks like testing, performance, and error handling.

entries.name: Feature dev explorer agent maps existing implementations
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/agents/code-explorer.md` instructs the agent to trace feature behaviour end to end: find entry points, follow call chains, document layers and dependencies, capture algorithms, edge cases, and performance notes, and output a structured walkthrough with file and line references.

entries.name: Feature dev playbooks span discovery, architecture, and review
entries.description: Feature development relies on explorer, architect, and reviewer agents within the feature-dev plugin. This entry explains the hand-offs between the playbooks so the `feature-dev` flow remains cohesive across analysis and quality review.

entries.name: Feature dev reviewer reports only high-confidence issues
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/agents/code-reviewer.md` focuses reviews on CLAUDE.md rules, real defects, and significant quality gaps, scoring each finding 0-100 and only surfacing items with confidence 80 or higher alongside file paths, rationales, and fixes to keep feedback high-signal.

entries.name: PR review playbooks cover code, commentary, tests, and failures
entries.description: The PR review toolkit contributes agents for code review, comment vetting, test coverage analysis, silent failure hunting, type design, and code simplification. This summary aspect cross-references each playbook and clarifies how the `pr-review` workflow draws on them for comprehensive checks. It also anchors the testing, silent failure, type design, comment, and simplification playbooks under the shared `pr-review` tag so orchestration aspects connect back into agent coverage.

entries.name: PR test analyzer rates behavioural coverage gaps
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/pr-test-analyzer.md` reviews pull requests for behavioural test coverage, highlighting missing error paths or edge cases, rating each gap 1-10 by impact, and structuring output into summary, critical gaps, important improvements, quality issues, and positives.

entries.name: PR toolkit code reviewer automates CLAUDE.md compliance checks
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/code-reviewer.md` upgrades the review agent to the opus model, documents proactive trigger cases, scopes reviews to git diffs, and requires reporting only confidence >= 80 issues grouped as critical or important with paths, rule references, and fixes.

entries.name: Python SDK verifier agent audits configuration and security
entries.description: `plugins/agent-sdk-dev/agents/agent-sdk-verifier-py.md` positions the agent as a Python Claude Agent SDK auditor: it checks that `claude-agent-sdk` is installed, versions are current, environments and dependencies are documented, imports and permissions follow SDK patterns, security hygiene (.env, API keys) is in place, and delivers PASS/WARN/FAIL reports with critical issues, warnings, passes, and recommendations.

entries.name: Silent failure hunter enforces transparent error handling
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/silent-failure-hunter.md` makes the agent inventory every catch block, log, fallback, and message, flagging silent failures, broad catches, weak user feedback, or unjustified fallbacks per CLAUDE.md policies and detailing severity, hidden risks, and remediation steps.

entries.name: Type design analyzer scores invariants and encapsulation
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/type-design-analyzer.md` tasks the agent with enumerating a type's invariants, rating encapsulation, invariant expression, usefulness, and enforcement out of ten, and outlining strengths, concerns, and pragmatic improvements to keep domain models robust.

entries.name: TypeScript SDK verifier enforces ES module best practices
entries.description: `plugins/agent-sdk-dev/agents/agent-sdk-verifier-ts.md` guides a TypeScript-focused audit: confirm `@anthropic-ai/claude-agent-sdk` installation, ensure package.json sets ES modules, validate tsconfig targets, run `npx tsc --noEmit`, inspect scripts, environment secrets, permissions, and documentation, then summarise findings with severity-rated recommendations.

entries.name: PR reviewer agent flags proactive trigger cues
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/code-reviewer.md` lists three default launch scenarios for the reviewer: after completing a feature implementation, immediately after generating new utility code, and before creating a PR so high-risk issues are surfaced prior to handoff, reinforcing that the Task tool should spin this agent up without waiting for user prompts.

entries.name: Comment analyzer prompt enumerates three launch contexts
entries.description: The comment analyzer playbook calls out three moments to invoke the agent: after adding documentation comments, after Claude generates large explanations, and before finalizing a PR, ensuring comment accuracy checks happen before stale guidance ships.

entries.name: Code simplifier prompt prescribes automatic follow-ups
entries.description: `code-simplifier.md` directs operators to rerun the agent after finishing a feature build, after bugfix patches, and after performance refactors, making simplification a standing follow-up for newly written work.

entries.name: PR test analyzer examples focus on pre-merge coverage sweeps
entries.description: The test analyzer prompt highlights three checkpointsâ€”new PR creation, subsequent updates, and pre-ready reviewsâ€”so maintainers know to run the agent whenever coverage might have drifted.

entries.name: Silent failure hunter examples target risky error-handling updates
entries.description: `silent-failure-hunter.md` instructs teams to launch the agent after adding API fallbacks, when reviewing PRs with new try/catch blocks, and after refactoring error handling, keeping hidden failures from slipping in.

entries.name: Type design analyzer flags when to audit new models
entries.description: `type-design-analyzer.md` tells operators to call the agent both when introducing a new domain type and when preparing pull requests that add several models, so invariant audits happen before merge.

entries.name: VS Code recommendations complement devcontainer installs
entries.description: `.vscode/extensions.json` recommends ESLint, Prettier, Remote Containers, and GitLens, deliberately omitting `anthropic.claude-code` because the devcontainer preinstalls it via `customizations`. The list mirrors `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json`â€™s extension block, so local clones prompted by VS Code and remote devcontainers launched through Docker converge on the same lint/format/history tooling.

entries.name: VS Code remote session mirrors devcontainer state
entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` runs as `remoteUser: node`, binds volumes for shared command history and `/home/node/.claude`, exports `CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR`, `NODE_OPTIONS`, and `POWERLEVEL9K_DISABLE_GITSTATUS`, and mounts the workspace with `consistency=delegated` so VS Code file watchers stay fast. Coupled with `waitFor: postStartCommand`, the editor only attaches after the firewall bootstrap succeeds, keeping sessions aligned with the hardened runtime.

entries.name: Devcontainer pins Prettier-on-save without auto lint fixes
entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` enforces `editor.formatOnSave: true` with Prettier as the default formatter, sets `editor.codeActionsOnSave.source.fixAll.eslint` to "explicit" so eslint fix-all runs only when requested, and installs `esbenp.prettier-vscode` through `customizations.vscode.extensions` so the formatter is always present inside the container.

entries.name: Devcontainer standardises zsh shell and persistent history
entries.description: `.devcontainer/Dockerfile` installs zsh-in-docker, sets `PROMPT_COMMAND='history -a'`, exports `SHELL=/bin/zsh`, and pins `EDITOR`/`VISUAL` to `nano`, while `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` makes zsh the default integrated terminal profile. Combined with the mounted `/commandhistory` volume, everyone lands in the same shell theme with shared history regardless of entry point.

entries.name: Git delta is pinned per architecture during build
entries.description: `.devcontainer/Dockerfile` resolves the container architecture with `dpkg --print-architecture`, downloads `git-delta_${GIT_DELTA_VERSION}_${ARCH}.deb`, installs it via `dpkg -i`, and deletes the package afterward so the image only keeps the binary. Patching git-delta this way honours the `GIT_DELTA_VERSION` build arg and keeps colourised diffs consistent across contributors.

entries.name: Zsh-in-docker bundles git prompt and fzf keybindings
entries.description: The zsh bootstrap in `.devcontainer/Dockerfile` runs `zsh-in-docker.sh` with `-p git -p fzf`, appends sourcing of `/usr/share/doc/fzf/examples/key-bindings.zsh` and `completion.zsh`, drops in a history appender snippet, and passes `-x` so zsh becomes the login shell automatically. That setup delivers Powerlevel10k with git status, fuzzy history search, and zsh completions without manual dotfile tweaks.

entries.name: VS Code terminal profiles pin zsh default with bash fallback
entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` sets `terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.linux` to `zsh` and explicitly defines `zsh` and `bash` profiles, flagging the bash fallback with the `terminal-bash` icon so developers can recognize it instantly if they switch shells.

entries.name: Powerlevel10k disables gitstatus to keep prompts responsive
entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` exports `POWERLEVEL9K_DISABLE_GITSTATUS=true` in `containerEnv`, disabling the gitstatus daemon so Powerlevel10k stays responsive even on huge repos while still retaining the themed prompt installed by zsh-in-docker. Because it is a container-level env var, both the VS Code integrated terminal and ad-hoc `docker exec` shells pick up the same snappy prompt behaviour.

entries.name: VS Code recommends the ESLint extension to mirror CLI checks
entries.description: `.vscode/extensions.json` pins `dbaeumer.vscode-eslint`, ensuring remote attach sessions surface the same lint diagnostics and fix-all quick actions that Claude emits when running eslint through slash commands.

entries.name: VS Code bundles GitLens for commit context during Claude sessions
entries.description: By recommending `eamodio.gitlens`, the workspace gives operators blame, author heatmaps, and history explorers inside the same container Claude edits, making it easier to supply reviewers with provenance or pick safe refactor targets.

entries.name: Devcontainer firewall enforces allowlist egress
entries.description: `.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` snapshots Docker DNS NAT rules, flushes iptables, destroys any existing `allowed-domains` ipset, and rebuilds it by aggregating GitHub `web`, `api`, and `git` CIDRs before resolving curated domains like npm, Anthropic APIs, Statsig, and VS Code endpoints. It then admits the host LAN `/24`, drops all other outbound traffic with `icmp-admin-prohibited`, and verifies the policy by failing `https://example.com` while succeeding `https://api.github.com`. The devcontainer `postStartCommand` runs the script on every boot so the allowlist is always enforced.

entries.name: Devcontainer image preinstalls Claude Code tooling
entries.description: `.devcontainer/Dockerfile` starts from `node:20`, installs base tooling (git, gh, iptables/ipset, jq, fzf, zsh), sets `DEVCONTAINER=true`, and pins Git Delta plus the `zsh-in-docker` theme via build args so upgrades stay controlled. It grants the node user `/usr/local/share/npm-global`, switches the default shell to zsh, installs `@anthropic-ai/claude-code@${CLAUDE_CODE_VERSION}`, and prepares `/workspace` and `/home/node/.claude` for the volumes declared in the devcontainer, yielding a reproducible Claude CLI environment.

entries.name: Git attributes keep shell tooling devcontainer-safe
entries.description: `.gitattributes` sets `* text=auto eol=lf` plus an explicit `*.sh` rule so Windows contributors still commit LF endings. That guarantees bash assets like `.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` run without CRLF bugs when the devcontainer boots and replays the firewall.

entries.name: PowerShell launcher provisions and enters the devcontainer
entries.description: `Script/run_devcontainer_claude_code.ps1` accepts an explicit `-Backend docker|podman`, verifies both the container runtime and `devcontainer` CLI are installed, and for Podman initialises/starts the `claudeVM` machine before setting it as default. It then runs `devcontainer up`, locates the container by label, and chains `claude; exec zsh` so Windows contributors land inside the prepared shell with the CLI preloaded.

entries.name: Devcontainer volumes persist Claude config and shell history
entries.description: `.devcontainer/Dockerfile` seeds `/commandhistory` with a `PROMPT_COMMAND` appender and prepares `/home/node/.claude`, while `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` mounts dedicated volumes onto those paths so shell history, Claude CLI config, and `security_warnings_state_<session>.json` files survive rebuilds. That persistence keeps security suppressions effective across sessions and preserves operator audit trails.

entries.name: Devcontainer caps Node processes to 4GB
entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` sets `NODE_OPTIONS=--max-old-space-size=4096` alongside `POWERLEVEL9K_DISABLE_GITSTATUS=true`, capping heap usage for Node-based tooling and trimming heavy prompt status updates. The cap keeps Claude Code analyses and Bun scripts from exhausting container memory and preserves responsive shells on large repositories.

entries.name: Devcontainer grants node user a writable global npm prefix
entries.description: `.devcontainer/Dockerfile` gives `node` ownership of `/usr/local/share`, sets `NPM_CONFIG_PREFIX=/usr/local/share/npm-global`, and adds that bin path to `PATH`. This guarantees global npm installs like `@anthropic-ai/claude-code` land in a node-owned directory without sudo, preventing permission fights when developers upgrade tooling inside the container.

entries.name: Dockerfile whitelists init-firewall for passwordless sudo
entries.description: `.devcontainer/Dockerfile` installs `init-firewall.sh` to `/usr/local/bin`, switches to root to mark it executable, and writes `/etc/sudoers.d/node-firewall` granting the node user passwordless access only to that script. Coupled with the devcontainer `postStartCommand`, the firewall can be applied at boot without broader sudo privileges or interactive prompts.

entries.name: Devcontainer apt install seeds firewall and CLI toolchain
entries.description: `.devcontainer/Dockerfile` updates apt and installs less, git, procps, sudo, fzf, zsh, man-db, unzip, gnupg2, gh, iptables, ipset, iproute2, dnsutils, aggregate, jq, nano, and vim. The bundle gives `init-firewall.sh` every dependency it needs (iptables/ipset/dnsutils/aggregate) while equipping developers with GitHub CLI, fuzzy finder, and editors as soon as the image builds.

entries.name: Devcontainer build args pin CLI release and timezone
entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` forwards build args for the Dockerfile: it mirrors the host timezone with `${localEnv:TZ:America/Los_Angeles}` and pins `CLAUDE_CODE_VERSION`, `GIT_DELTA_VERSION`, and `ZSH_IN_DOCKER_VERSION`. These knobs keep CLI and tooling upgrades deliberate while letting contributors override the timezone without editing the image.

entries.name: Devcontainer exports CLI memory and prompt environment defaults
entries.description: The `containerEnv` block in `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` sets `NODE_OPTIONS=--max-old-space-size=4096` to curb Node OOMs, points `CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR` at the mounted `/home/node/.claude`, and disables Powerlevel10k git status (`POWERLEVEL9K_DISABLE_GITSTATUS=true`) to keep prompt rendering snappy during large repo operations.

entries.name: Devcontainer bind mounts workspace with delegated consistency
entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` binds the local checkout into `/workspace` via `workspaceMount: source=${localWorkspaceFolder},target=/workspace,type=bind,consistency=delegated` and sets `workspaceFolder: /workspace`. Delegated consistency speeds macOS file I/O, and pairing the mount with `remoteUser: node` ensures the claude CLI and editors operate against the right paths without sudo.

entries.name: Dockerfile sets DEVCONTAINER flag for in-environment detection
entries.description: `.devcontainer/Dockerfile` exports `DEVCONTAINER=true` once the image switches to the `node` user. Tools like the security reminder hook and CLI helpers can use that flag to detect they're running inside the managed container and adjust behaviour (for example, locating volume mounts) without additional config.

entries.name: PowerShell launcher validates backend binaries
entries.description: `Script/run_devcontainer_claude_code.ps1` uses `Get-Command` to verify the chosen backend (`docker` or `podman`) and the `devcontainer` CLI exist, failing with guidance if either is missing.

entries.name: PowerShell launcher prepares Podman claudeVM
entries.description: `Script/run_devcontainer_claude_code.ps1` initialises/starts the `claudeVM` Podman machine and passes `--docker-path podman` to `devcontainer up`, making the VS Code workflow podman-compatible without manual flags.

entries.name: PowerShell launcher locates container by devcontainer label
entries.description: `Script/run_devcontainer_claude_code.ps1` filters `docker|podman ps` by `label=devcontainer.local_folder=<path>` to resolve the container ID before running `claude; exec zsh`, avoiding brittle name assumptions.

entries.name: PowerShell launcher verifies Docker daemon
entries.description: When `-Backend docker` is chosen, `Script/run_devcontainer_claude_code.ps1` runs `docker info` and aborts if Docker Desktop is down, preventing confusing `devcontainer up` failures.

entries.name: Devcontainer volumes are namespaced per container ID
entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` names the persistent volumes `claude-code-bashhistory-${devcontainerId}` and `claude-code-config-${devcontainerId}`, giving each devcontainer instance its own shell history and Claude config store so parallel checkouts do not leak state while still surviving rebuilds.

entries.name: Podman launcher sets claudeVM as the default connection
entries.description: `Script/run_devcontainer_claude_code.ps1` calls `podman system connection default claudeVM` after starting the machine so later Podman invocations target the managed claudeVM context automatically before running `devcontainer up`.

entries.name: Devcontainer launcher restricts backend flag to docker or podman
entries.description: The PowerShell wrapper declares `[ValidateSet('docker','podman')]` on the `-Backend` parameter so the script fails fast for unsupported runtimes instead of executing partial setup commands against an unknown engine.

entries.name: Dockerfile pre-creates workspace directories with node ownership
entries.description: `Dockerfile` creates `/workspace` and `/home/node/.claude` and assigns them to the node user so bind mounts and persisted config attach without additional chmod steps.

entries.name: Windows launcher starts Claude before dropping into zsh
entries.description: `Script/run_devcontainer_claude_code.ps1` attaches to the running container and executes `claude; exec zsh`, ensuring the CLI greets contributors and then hands off to the standard zsh session without exiting.

entries.name: Changelog chronicles CLI and plugin milestones
entries.description: `CHANGELOG.md` chronicles Claude Code releases from the 2.x plugin era back to early 0.2 builds. Recent entries capture 2.0.15's resume fixes for rewritten files, 2.0.14's MCP toggles and inline env-var safeguards, 2.0.13's `/plugin` fix on native builds, and 2.0.11's 1.4k-token system-prompt trim plus IDE shortcut repairs. The 2.0.12 milestone documents the plugin system launch with `/plugin install|enable|validate` and `extraKnownMarketplaces`, 2.0.10 logged the terminal renderer rewrite and bash permission fixes, and the 1.0.124 note calls out the `CLAUDE_BASH_NO_LOGIN` escape hatch while 1.0.123 introduces the SlashCommand tool. Earlier 2.0.0 and 0.2.x notes trace `/rewind`, `/usage`, MCP scope renames, and slash-command tooling, giving maintainers a linear record of CLI, IDE, and safety behaviour changes.

entries.name: License defers rights to Anthropic commercial terms
entries.description: `LICENSE.md` is a single-line notice that the code is Â© Anthropic PBC and subject to the Commercial Terms of Service, signalling that Claude Code is distributed under Anthropic's proprietary terms rather than an open-source license.

entries.name: README orients newcomers and quickstarts the CLI
entries.description: `README.md` positions Claude Code as an agentic coding companion across terminal, IDE, and GitHub surfaces, highlights the Node.js â‰¥18 requirement via the badge header, links to the official documentation hub, and embeds `demo.gif` to preview the experience. The "Get started" section reduces onboarding to `npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code` followed by `claude`, "Reporting Bugs" directs `/bug` submissions or GitHub issues, "Connect on Discord" links to the Claude Developers server, and the data usage section links out to the detailed policy plus Commercial Terms and Privacy Policy.

entries.name: Security policy channels findings through HackerOne
entries.description: `SECURITY.md` thanks good-faith researchers, reiterates that protecting Claude Code users is Anthropic's top priority, and directs all validated reports to the anthropic-vdp HackerOne submission form with a pointer to the public VDP guidelinesâ€”no security@ email or ad-hoc channelâ€”so fixes stay within the managed disclosure program.

entries.name: PR Review Toolkit README choreographs multi-agent reviews
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/README.md` maps each of the six review agents to its trigger phrases and scoring rubric (code-reviewer 0â€“100 coverage, silent-failure-hunter for runtime risks, pr-test-analyzer for CI, comment-analyzer for discussion triage, type-design-analyzer 1â€“10 API scores, code-simplifier for polish), walks through individual vs comprehensive usage patterns, and closes with installation notes (`/plugins` search or manual settings) so operators can launch the toolkit quickly.

entries.name: Docs steer support through /bug, GitHub, and Discord
entries.description: `README.md` tells users to report problems with the in-product `/bug` command or GitHub issues, while `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/config.yml` sets `blank_issues_enabled: false` and advertises Discord, the docs hub, quickstart, and troubleshooting guides via `contact_links`. Together they funnel operational feedback into curated channels and keep GitHub issues focused on actionable work.

entries.name: README discloses Claude Code data collection safeguards
entries.description: The README's "Data collection, usage, and retention" section explains that Claude Code records acceptance metrics, conversation transcripts, and `/bug` feedback, links to the detailed data usage policy, Commercial Terms, and Privacy Policy, and highlights safeguards such as limited retention, restricted access, and a commitment not to reuse feedback for unrelated model training or product decisions.

entries.name: Launcher help block documents Windows devcontainer bootstrap
entries.description: The comment-based help in `Script/run_devcontainer_claude_code.ps1` spells out the synopsis, expected repository layout, and mandatory `-Backend docker|podman` parameter, then the script checks both the chosen backend and the `devcontainer` CLI before running. Podman flows initialise/start the `claudeVM` machine and set the default connection, while Docker flows verify the Desktop daemon before calling `devcontainer up`.

entries.name: Devcontainer manifest preinstalls core VS Code tooling
entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` lists `anthropic.claude-code`, ESLint, Prettier, GitLens, and the Remote Containers extension under `customizations.vscode.extensions`, so VS Code automatically installs the same helper set when attaching and developers land in a ready-to-debug workspace without chasing recommendations.

entries.name: README invites maintainers to Claude Developers Discord
entries.description: The README's "Connect on Discord" section links to https://anthropic.com/discord and frames it as the place to get help, share feedback, and discuss projects with other Claude Code developers, making the Discord server the real-time complement to GitHub issues and `/bug` reports.

entries.name: PR review toolkit agents share a structured output template
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/README.md` states every agent reports clear issue identification, file:line references, impact explanation, improvement suggestions, and severity ordering, establishing a consistent review format regardless of which specialist runs.

entries.name: PR review toolkit recommends stage-specific agent checklists
entries.description: The README maps which agents to run before committing (code-reviewer, silent-failure-hunter), before opening a PR (pr-test-analyzer, comment-analyzer, type-design-analyzer, code-reviewer), and after review (code-simplifier) so teams apply the toolkit proactively instead of reactively.

entries.name: PR review toolkit documents parallel and sequential execution modes
entries.description: The README explains that agents can be launched in parallel for speedâ€”â€œRun pr-test-analyzer and comment-analyzer in parallelâ€â€”or sequentially when one report should inform the next, guiding reviewers on how to balance latency and context sharing.

entries.name: PR review toolkit tips emphasise specificity and iteration
entries.description: Documentation urges reviewers to target the right agent, run reviews before opening PRs, resolve critical findings first, rerun agents after fixes, and avoid scanning the entire codebase to keep results focused on the latest changes.

entries.name: Troubleshooting guidance covers agents that fail to trigger
entries.description: When a requested review does not launch, the README advises asking more specific questions, naming the agent explicitly, and describing the concernâ€”such as â€œtest coverageâ€â€”so the toolkit routes the request correctly.

entries.name: Troubleshooting guidance narrows agent review scope
entries.description: If an agent analyzes the wrong files, the README recommends specifying the target files, referencing the PR or branch, or asking for â€œrecent changesâ€ coverage so Claude constrains the analysis window.

entries.name: README outlines an end-to-end PR review workflow
entries.description: The documentation chains the toolkit with other automation: run build-validator before reviews, pair it with project-specific agents, then follow a six-step sequence from writing code through code-simplifier polish before opening the PR.

entries.name: PR review toolkit documentation highlights complementary automation
entries.description: The README calls out build-validator and project-specific agents as natural companions so teams can run build/test checks, then hand reviews to the specialist agents in the same workflow.

entries.name: Security policy routes all reports through HackerOne
entries.description: `SECURITY.md` directs researchers to submit validated vulnerabilities via the Anthropic HackerOne form at https://hackerone.com/anthropic-vdp/reports/new, making that portal the single supported intake channel for Claude Code issues.

entries.name: Security policy defers to Anthropic VDP guidelines
entries.description: The same document points reporters to the Anthropic Vulnerability Disclosure Program page for scope and rules, ensuring Claude Code investigations follow the broader corporate disclosure guidelines.

entries.name: Security policy thanks good-faith researchers explicitly
entries.description: `SECURITY.md` opens by recognising researchers who act in good faith and reiterates that protecting user data is Anthropic's top priority, signalling the collaborative stance the team expects during disclosure.

entries.name: LICENSE.md ties usage to Anthropic Commercial Terms
entries.description: `LICENSE.md` explicitly reserves all rights to Anthropic PBC and points consumers to the Commercial Terms of Service, making clear that Claude Code is proprietary and governed by Anthropicâ€™s broader legal agreement rather than an open-source license.

entries.name: PreToolUse hook governance unifies examples and security
entries.description: `examples/hooks/bash_command_validator_example.py` documents the governance model: prototype hooks exit with code 1 on malformed tool payloads, exit 2 when enforcement should block execution, and print actionable stderr guidance. The security plugin's `hooks.json` and `security_reminder_hook.py` apply the same PreToolUse contract for real edit/write requests, showing how sample hooks graduate into enforced guardrails.

entries.name: Sample bash validator hook enforces ripgrep usage
entries.description: `examples/hooks/bash_command_validator_example.py` wires a Bash PreToolUse hook that regex-matches raw `grep` invocations and `find -name` lookups, prompting developers to swap in ripgrep alternatives. It surfaces each mismatch as bullet-point stderr output and returns exit code 2 so Claude blocks the command until the operator adopts the faster patterns.

entries.name: Security reminder hook blocks risky edits
entries.description: `projects/claude-code/plugins/security-guidance/hooks/security_reminder_hook.py` inspects Edit/Write/MultiEdit payloads for high-risk constructs (GitHub Actions templating, child_process.exec, eval/new Function, DOM XSS sinks, pickle, os.system), stores per-session warnings in `~/.claude/security_warnings_state_<session>.json`, and blocks repeat violations with exit code 2. It honours `ENABLE_SECURITY_REMINDER=0`, logs parse failures to `/tmp/security-warnings-log.txt`, and on 10% of runs clears state files older than 30 days so the reminder stays responsive without leaving stale suppressions.

entries.name: Security guidance hooks config wires reminder script to edits
entries.description: `plugins/security-guidance/hooks/hooks.json` registers a PreToolUse hook that matches Edit, Write, and MultiEdit actions and executes `security_reminder_hook.py` via `${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT}`. This makes the reminder mandatory for every write-capable tool invocation, keeping the hook active even when the plugin is redistributed.

entries.name: Security reminder state persists via devcontainer volumes
entries.description: `plugins/security-guidance/hooks/security_reminder_hook.py` saves the warning ledger per CLI session under `~/.claude/security_warnings_state_<session>.json`, and `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` mounts a Docker volume at `/home/node/.claude` so those JSON files survive rebuilds. The hook also prunes records older than 30 days, meaning persistent suppressions stick across container restarts yet long-abandoned sessions eventually drop without manual cleanup.

entries.name: Security reminder flags risky GitHub Actions templating
entries.description: `plugins/security-guidance/hooks/security_reminder_hook.py` includes a `github_actions_workflow` rule that triggers whenever a file under `.github/workflows/` is edited. The reminder enumerates vulnerable `${{ github.event.* }}` expansions and links to GitHub's workflow injection guide so maintainers treat incoming issue metadata as untrusted before shipping CI changes.

entries.name: Security reminder steers Node code away from child_process.exec
entries.description: The security reminder hook watches for `child_process.exec`, `exec(`, and `execSync(` occurrences and advises maintainers to swap in `src/utils/execFileNoThrow.ts`. The message explains why execFile avoids shell injection, preserves Windows compatibility, and returns structured output so developers can keep automation safe without losing ergonomics.

entries.name: Security reminder warns on eval and new Function usage
entries.description: Two security patterns in `security_reminder_hook.py` scan for `new Function` and `eval(` calls. When triggered, the hook explains the injection risks and recommends safer alternatives like `JSON.parse` or refactoring without runtime compilation, blocking execution until the author confirms the construct is truly needed.

entries.name: Security reminder blocks dangerous DOM sink patterns
entries.description: The hook also matches `dangerouslySetInnerHTML`, `document.write`, and direct `.innerHTML` assignments. It surfaces guidance to sanitize HTML or prefer safe DOM APIs, forcing a conscious review before code that could introduce XSS ships to production.

entries.name: Security reminder cautions against pickle and os.system
entries.description: For Python edits, `security_reminder_hook.py` looks for `pickle` usage and `os.system` imports, warning that untrusted deserialization or shell-outs can lead to arbitrary code execution. The reminder pushes authors toward safer serialization formats or static command strings before the tool resumes.

entries.name: Security reminder hook matches only edit tools
entries.description: `plugins/security-guidance/hooks/hooks.json` registers the Python hook for `Edit|Write|MultiEdit` payloads, avoiding latency on read-only tools while still guarding file modifications.

entries.name: Security reminder hook inspects MultiEdit payloads holistically
entries.description: `plugins/security-guidance/hooks/security_reminder_hook.py` flattens `tool_input['edits']` when tool_name is `MultiEdit`, joining all `new_string` fragments before scanning for risky patterns. The aggregation prevents an attacker from splitting dangerous code across edits to dodge the reminder.

entries.name: Security reminder logs JSON parse failures for debugging
entries.description: If tool input cannot be parsed, `security_reminder_hook.py` records the exception to `/tmp/security-warnings-log.txt` and exits with code 1 so maintainers can diagnose malformed payloads without suppressing the hook entirely.

entries.name: Security reminder debug log timestamps hook activity
entries.description: `security_reminder_hook.py` funnels every diagnostic message through `debug_log`, stamping entries with millisecond resolution and appending them to `/tmp/security-warnings-log.txt`. That timestamped trail helps operators correlate reminder blocks with the triggering edits without letting logging failures abort the hook.

entries.name: Security reminder loads warning state defensively
entries.description: `load_state` checks for `security_warnings_state_<session>.json`, returns an empty set when the file is missing, and falls back cleanly if JSON parsing fails. That resilience keeps stale or corrupted state from disabling the reminder while still honouring prior suppressions when the cache is intact.

entries.name: Security reminder precreates ~/.claude before persisting state
entries.description: `save_state` proactively calls `os.makedirs` on the state directory before writing the JSON payload, guaranteeing the per-session suppression ledger survives even on fresh containers where `~/.claude` has not been created yet.

entries.name: Security reminder normalizes tool paths before scanning
entries.description: `check_patterns` strips leading slashes from file paths before evaluating path-based rules like the GitHub Actions matcher. Normalization makes the hook catch dangerous edits whether the tool payload uses absolute or workspace-relative paths.

entries.name: Security reminder cleanup guards against filesystem errors
entries.description: `cleanup_old_state_files` iterates over `~/.claude` entries, skips straight past missing directories, and ignores per-file deletion failures. The defensive cleanup keeps the suppression cache tidy without ever blocking tool execution because of filesystem race conditions.

entries.name: Bug report form captures regression signals and environment
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.yml` walks reporters through a preflight check (searched dupes, single bug, latest CLI) before collecting actual vs expected behaviour, numbered reproduction steps, optional shell-rendered logs, regression status with last working version, API platform, OS, terminal, and the `claude --version` output, so support receives a reproducible case with environment metadata up front.

entries.name: Documentation issue form drives precise copy fixes
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/documentation.yml` forces authors to classify the doc issue (missing, unclear, outdated, typo, broken link, missing examples), point to the URL/section, paste the current wording, explain the gap, and submit a concrete rewrite plus impact level, turning feedback into scoped copy changes instead of vague complaints.

entries.name: Feature request template frames roadmap inputs
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.yml` starts with a duplicate-sweep checklist, then demands a problem statement, ideal solution, and any workaround, tags the ask with a priority and category (CLI flags, TUI, MCP integration, performance, configuration, docs, SDK, etc.), and invites a step-by-step use case so roadmap grooming sees both urgency and context.

entries.name: Issue template config funnels general support off GitHub
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/config.yml` shuts off blank issues and replaces them with quick links to Discord chat, the docs hub, the quickstart, and troubleshooting guides, funnelling support questions away from GitHub while steering real bugs, features, docs, and model reports into structured forms.

entries.name: Model behaviour template secures safety audit trails
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/model_behavior.yml` couples behaviour categories with required fields for the exact prompt, Claudeâ€™s actions, expected outcome, affected files, permission mode, reproducibility, model, and impact, giving safety reviewers a forensic snapshot before investigating policy or product regressions.

entries.name: Bug report form captures platform and terminal matrices
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.yml` enumerates platform (Anthropic, Bedrock, Vertex, Other), OS (macOS, Windows, Ubuntu/Debian, other Linux, other), terminal (Terminal.app, Warp, VS Code, PowerShell, WSL, etc.), and requires the `claude --version` string so support can cluster incidents by runtime without extra intake.

entries.name: Feature request template enforces priority and domain triage
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.yml` pairs the Criticalâ†’Low priority scale with a category selector (CLI flags, TUI, MCP integration, performance, configuration, docs, SDK, etc.) plus free-form workaround and use-case sections, letting product triage weigh urgency against scope.

entries.name: Model behaviour template bins incident types for safety review
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/model_behavior.yml` makes reporters bucket incidents (unauthorised writes, out-of-scope reads, ignored instructions, subagent drift, refusals, behavioural swings) before attaching transcripts, reproduction notes, and impact, so triage routes infra regressions separately from trust & safety escalations.

entries.name: Bug report template prelabels issues
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.yml` prefixes new issue titles with `[BUG] ` and auto-applies the `bug` label, so triagers can spot production defects before any manual tagging.

entries.name: Bug report logs render as shell code
entries.description: The `Error Messages/Logs` field in `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.yml` sets `render: shell`, preserving CLI formatting when reporters paste stack traces so engineers can read them without markdown mangling.

entries.name: Bug report captures active model
entries.description: Reporters must choose the `Claude Model` dropdown in `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.yml`, which explicitly references the `/model` command so support can triage regressions by model tier.

entries.name: Bug report terminal picker covers CI runs
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.yml` includes a `Terminal/Shell` dropdown with `Non-interactive/CI environment`, ensuring automation regressions can be grouped separately from local shells.

entries.name: Docs template stamps `[DOCS]` and documentation label
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/documentation.yml` auto-prefixes titles with `[DOCS] ` and applies the `documentation` label so copy edits surface immediately in the docs backlog.

entries.name: Docs issue form classifies feedback
entries.description: The `Documentation Type` dropdown in `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/documentation.yml` buckets problems into missing content, unclear guidance, outdated info, typos, broken links, or missing examples, guiding writers toward the right fix.

entries.name: Docs issue form rates impact
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/documentation.yml` asks reporters to choose High/Medium/Low impact, making it clear when missing docs block a feature versus causing minor confusion.

entries.name: Docs issue form demands suggested copy
entries.description: The `Suggested Improvement` textarea in `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/documentation.yml` is required and prompts users to draft replacement text, turning feedback into actionable edits.

entries.name: Feature request template prelabels enhancements
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.yml` prefixes issues with `[FEATURE] ` and applies the `enhancement` label so roadmap review queues stay organized.

entries.name: Feature requests must pass duplicate sweep
entries.description: The Preflight checklist in `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.yml` forces authors to confirm they've searched existing enhancement issues and are filing a single ask, which keeps the backlog deduplicated.

entries.name: Feature requests tag their domain
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.yml` ships a `Feature Category` dropdown covering CLI flags, TUI, file ops, MCP integration, performance, configuration, SDK, docs, and other areas so PMs can route asks by domain.

entries.name: Feature requests document concrete scenarios
entries.description: The optional `Use Case Example` section in `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.yml` asks for step-by-step real workflows, giving designers context beyond the headline ask.

entries.name: Model behavior form flags incidents upfront
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/model_behavior.yml` prefixes submissions with `[MODEL] ` and assigns the `model` label so trust & safety triage sees anomalous behaviour immediately.

entries.name: Model behavior preflight protects sensitive data
entries.description: The Preflight checklist in `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/model_behavior.yml` requires reporters to confirm they've searched existing incidents and removed secrets, preventing private data from landing in public issues.

entries.name: Model behavior reports capture permission mode
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/model_behavior.yml` asks whether Accept Edits was on, off, or unknown, giving investigators vital context about how Claude gained write access.

entries.name: Model behavior form captures file diffs
entries.description: The `Files Affected` textarea in `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/model_behavior.yml` uses `render: shell`, prompting reporters to list touched files verbatim so reviewers can diff damage quickly.

entries.name: Model behavior template invites transcript snippets
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/model_behavior.yml` provides a `Relevant Conversation` field rendered as markdown so reporters can paste Claude's explanations alongside the incident, preserving context for auditors.

entries.name: Agent SDK dev plugin scaffolds new Claude Agent apps
entries.description: `plugins/agent-sdk-dev/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` pairs with `commands/new-sdk-app.md` to guide developers through creating a fresh SDK app, including environment questions and file layout recommendations. The plugin surfaces verifier agents for TypeScript and Python so Claude can validate SDK integrations after scaffolding.

entries.name: Agent SDK plugin links scaffolding and post-check verifiers
entries.description: The agent-sdk-dev plugin ensures developers can scaffold a project and immediately run language-specific verifiers. This overview ties the command and verifiers together under the shared `agent-sdk` initiative.

entries.name: Commit commands plugin bundles git workflows
entries.description: Commit, commit-push-pr, and clean-gone slash commands ship together via the marketplace bundle entry `commit-commands` (backed by the three prompt files). This summary shows how the `git-workflow` toolkit drives git hygiene directly from Claude.

entries.name: Commit commands plugin scripts git branch, commit, and PR flows
entries.description: `plugins/commit-commands/commands/commit.md`, `commit-push-pr.md`, and `clean_gone.md` define Claude prompts that restrict tool usage to `git`/`gh` invocations, guiding agents through staging, committing, pushing, and cleaning gone branches (including worktree removal). These commands underpin the marketplace entry `commit-commands`, giving developers reproducible git workflows straight from Claude.

entries.name: Feature dev plugin bundles CLI ritual and support agents
entries.description: Feature-dev's plugin manifest, slash command, explorer, architect, and reviewer playbooks form a cohesive workflow for scoped discovery, architecture decisions, and quality review before implementation.

entries.name: Feature development plugin enforces multi-phase delivery ritual
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` registers the feature-dev bundle, while `commands/feature-dev.md` lays out a seven-phase plan (discovery, exploration, clarifying questions, architecture design, implementation, quality review, summary) with explicit expectations like spawning explorer/architect agents and deferring implementation until approvals. This structure keeps Claude-led feature work consistent and auditable.

entries.name: Marketplace manifest packages Claude Code plugins
entries.description: `.claude-plugin/marketplace.json` declares a `claude-code-plugins` bundle with five entries: Agent SDK dev kit, PR review toolkit, commit workflow commands, feature dev workflow, and security guidance hook. Each plugin supplies metadata (author, category, version) and a relative `source` path into `./plugins`, so publishing this manifest loads the curated set of development, productivity, and security helpers in one install.

entries.name: PR Review Toolkit aggregates six specialized review agents
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` and `README.md` document agents covering comments, tests, silent failures, type design, general review, and code simplification. Each agent advertises trigger phrases and focus areas, allowing Claude to route review requests automatically or in bundles for comprehensive PR analysis.

entries.name: PR review toolkit bundles command and specialist agents
entries.description: The PR review toolkit plugin pools slash commands and agents covering code review, test gaps, silent failures, comment accuracy, type design, and code simplification. This aspect summarizes how the bundle accelerates PR analysis and links to every component.

entries.name: Feature dev plugin manifest
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` ships version 1.0.0 authored by Siddharth Bidasaria with a development-category description of the feature workflow bundle.

entries.name: PR review toolkit manifest
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` records Daisy as author of version 1.0.0 and categorises the bundle under productivity.

entries.name: Agent SDK plugin manifest
entries.description: `plugins/agent-sdk-dev/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` captures version 1.0.0 with Siddharth Bidasaria as author, documenting provenance for the SDK dev kit.

entries.name: Security guidance plugin manifest
entries.description: `plugins/security-guidance/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` documents version 1.0.0 from David Dworken describing the security reminder hook bundle for marketplace distribution.

entries.name: Marketplace bundle metadata
entries.description: `.claude-plugin/marketplace.json` defines the `claude-code-plugins` bundle (version 1.0.0) owned by Anthropic, listing agent-sdk-dev, pr-review-toolkit, commit-commands, feature-dev, and security-guidance with per-plugin categories.

entries.name: Marketplace manifest lists commit-commands under productivity
entries.description: `marketplace.json` registers the commit workflow bundle as version 1.0.0 with category `productivity`, pointing to `./plugins/commit-commands` for the source.

entries.name: Marketplace manifest lists Anthropic support as bundle owner
entries.description: `.claude-plugin/marketplace.json` registers the bundle owner as Anthropic with `support@anthropic.com`, giving operators a single contact for marketplace distribution issues.

entries.name: Marketplace manifest credits plugin maintainers
entries.description: The manifest records individual maintainersâ€”Siddharth Bidasaria for feature-dev and David Dworken for security-guidanceâ€”alongside Anthropic-owned entries, so support requests route to the right steward.

entries.name: Commit+push+PR plugin freezes allowed Bash subcommands
entries.description: The plugin command enumerates `Bash(git checkout --branch:*)`, `Bash(git add:*)`, `Bash(git status:*)`, `Bash(git commit:*)`, `Bash(git push:*)`, and `Bash(gh pr create:*)`, preventing helper scripts from sneaking in arbitrary shell commands during the workflow.

entries.name: PR toolkit README lists task-specific trigger phrases
entries.description: Each agent section pairs its focus with sample prompts (e.g., "Review the error handling" â†’ silent-failure-hunter), helping operators summon the right reviewer without memorising slash syntax.

entries.name: PR toolkit README explains individual vs comprehensive runs
entries.description: The guide shows how to call agents singly (e.g., "Check if the tests cover edge cases") or request a full review by naming multiple aspects, making it clear how Claude fans out the toolkit.

entries.name: PR toolkit README reminds simplifier preserves behaviour
entries.description: The README's code-simplifier section calls out that the agent refines clarity without changing functionality, reinforcing that it is a post-review polish step rather than a rewrite bot.

entries.name: Claude responder action handles @claude mentions across issues and PRs
entries.description: `.github/workflows/claude.yml` only fires when `@claude` appears in a comment body, review body, or issue title/body via its `if` guards, then runs `actions/checkout@v4` with `fetch-depth: 1` under read-only `contents/issues/pull-requests` plus `id-token: write` before invoking `anthropics/claude-code-action@beta` with the Anthropic API key.

entries.name: Claude triage workflow labels incoming issues via MCP tools
entries.description: `.github/workflows/claude-issue-triage.yml` runs with `contents: read` and `issues: write`, writes `/tmp/claude-prompts/triage-prompt.txt` that forces `gh label list` first and bans commenting, spins up `docker run ghcr.io/github/github-mcp-server:sha-7aced2b` with `GITHUB_TOKEN`, and feeds both files into the base action with a 5-minute tool timeout inside a 10-minute job.

entries.name: Issue intake pipeline routes GitHub submissions to Claude triage
entries.description: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/config.yml` redirects general support to docs/Discord, while `issue-opened-dispatch.yml` forwards each new issue to `${{ secrets.ISSUE_OPENED_DISPATCH_TARGET_REPO }}` via repository dispatch and `claude-issue-triage.yml` consumes that metadata to auto-label, giving the structured templates a fully automated routing loop.

entries.name: Issue opened dispatch forwards events to external automation
entries.description: `.github/workflows/issue-opened-dispatch.yml` exports the issue URL, number, and title into env vars, resolves `${{ secrets.ISSUE_OPENED_DISPATCH_TARGET_REPO }}` as `TARGET_REPO`, and posts a repository dispatch with a fail-open `|| { exit 0; }` guard. The job runs with `issues: read` and `actions: write` and is capped at one minute so the relay never blocks reporters if the downstream automation flakes.

entries.name: Scheduled lock enforces seven-day quiet period on closed issues
entries.description: `.github/workflows/lock-closed-issues.yml` pages closed issues sorted by `updated: asc`, breaks once it encounters a thread updated within seven days, posts the standard lock notice, and locks with reason `resolved`, all under concurrency group `lock-threads` to avoid overlapping runs.

entries.name: Issue opened dispatch fails open with minimal timeout
entries.description: Running with `timeout-minutes: 1` and `actions: write`, the dispatch job treats any `gh api` error as a no-op via `|| { exit 0; }`, ensuring the issue intake flow fails open if the target repo is misconfigured or temporarily unavailable.

entries.name: Issue triage workflow writes MCP prompt file
entries.description: `.github/workflows/claude-issue-triage.yml` renders the prompt file with explicit instructions to run `gh label list`, enumerates each allowed MCP tool (get_issue, get_issue_comments, update_issue, search_issues, list_issues), and reiterates that the agent must only apply labelsâ€”no comments or other outputs.

entries.name: Issue triage spins GitHub MCP server container
entries.description: The triage workflow writes `/tmp/mcp-config/mcp-servers.json` pointing to `docker run -i --rm -e GITHUB_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN ghcr.io/github/github-mcp-server:sha-7aced2b`, so the action starts the MCP server on demand with the repo-scoped `GITHUB_TOKEN` without preinstalling binaries.

entries.name: Issue triage constrains Claude ToolUse
entries.description: The base action receives `allowed_tools: "Bash(gh label list),mcp__github__get_issue,mcp__github__get_issue_comments,mcp__github__update_issue,mcp__github__search_issues,mcp__github__list_issues"`, strictly limiting Claude to label discovery and MCP metadata fetches while blocking comments or arbitrary shell commands.

entries.name: Issue triage caps job runtime
entries.description: `.github/workflows/claude-issue-triage.yml` caps the job at 10 minutes and passes `timeout_minutes: "5"` to the action, guaranteeing the labeling agent canâ€™t hold onto the runner beyond five minutes even if the overall workflow budget is higher.

entries.name: Lock workflow serializes runs with concurrency group
entries.description: `.github/workflows/lock-closed-issues.yml` sets `concurrency: lock-threads`, preventing overlapping runs that could fight over the same backlog of stale issues.

entries.name: Lock script ignores pull requests
entries.description: Inside `lock-closed-issues.yml`, the GitHub Script step continues when `issue.pull_request` is present, so lock enforcement never touches PR threads that GitHub keeps open for discussion.

entries.name: Lock script skips already sealed threads
entries.description: The workflow checks `issue.locked` at the top of the loop and immediately continues, avoiding redundant comments when maintainers have already locked a conversation manually.

entries.name: @claude responder runs on assignment events
entries.description: `.github/workflows/claude.yml` listens for `issues` events of type `assigned` and then checks the issue title or body for `@claude`, letting maintainers summon the bot simply by assigning it to the thread.

entries.name: Claude dedupe exposes workflow_dispatch input
entries.description: `.github/workflows/claude-dedupe-issues.yml` defines a `workflow_dispatch` `issue_number` input so maintainers can rerun the dedupe command on any case without waiting for a new issue event.

entries.name: Claude responder pins actions/checkout to a commit SHA
entries.description: `.github/workflows/claude.yml` references `actions/checkout@11bd71901bbe5b1630ceea73d27597364c9af683`, locking the dependency to a reviewed commit instead of a floating tag to protect the automation from supply-chain changes.

entries.name: Claude responder grants id-token for downstream auth
entries.description: The workflowâ€™s job permissions include `id-token: write`, enabling the Claude action to mint OIDC tokens if it needs to authenticate with cloud resources while keeping all other scopes read-only.

entries.name: Claude issue triage job is limited to ten minutes
entries.description: `claude-issue-triage.yml` sets `timeout-minutes: 10`, bounding the automation so misbehaving MCP sessions cannot monopolize the runner.

entries.name: Claude issue triage uses minimal GitHub permissions
entries.description: The workflow grants only `contents: read` and `issues: write`, exactly matching the labels data it needs to update.

entries.name: Claude dedupe workflow caps runtime at ten minutes
entries.description: The job-level `timeout-minutes: 10` keeps `/dedupe` runs from hanging indefinitely on Actions infrastructure.

entries.name: Claude dedupe workflow uses contents read and issues write permissions
entries.description: The workflow requests only the access needed to fetch prompts and update issues, mirroring the triage jobâ€™s least-privilege model.

entries.name: Lock workflow posts a standard inactivity notice before sealing issues
entries.description: `lock-closed-issues.yml` comments `This issue has been automatically lockedâ€¦ please file a new issue` prior to calling `issues.lock`, giving users instructions before the thread is frozen.

entries.name: Issue triage workflow writes an MCP config pointing to the GitHub server container
entries.description: `claude-issue-triage.yml` generates `/tmp/mcp-config/mcp-servers.json` that runs `ghcr.io/github/github-mcp-server:sha-7aced2b` with the repository token, wiring Claude to GitHub MCP tools on demand.

entries.name: Issue-opened dispatch wires repo target and token via secrets
entries.description: The workflow exports `ISSUE_OPENED_DISPATCH_TARGET_REPO` and `ISSUE_OPENED_DISPATCH_TOKEN` into the job environment before calling `gh api repos/${TARGET_REPO}/dispatches`, letting ops retarget the downstream repo or rotate credentials without editing YAML.

entries.name: Issue-opened dispatch keeps minimal read/write scope
entries.description: The job declares `issues: read` and `actions: write` permissions, just enough to receive the webhook and fire a repository_dispatch event without granting commit access or broader scopes to the token.

entries.name: Bun script auto-closes stale duplicate GitHub issues
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` (Bun runtime) paginates older open issues via the GitHub REST API, finds bot-authored duplicate detection comments older than three days with no subsequent activity, checks for author thumbs-down reactions, extracts the canonical issue number, and then closes the issue with `state_reason: duplicate` plus an explanatory comment. `.github/workflows/auto-close-duplicates.yml` schedules this task daily at 09:00 UTC, installs Bun, and exports repository metadata so the script can call GitHub authenticated with `${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}`.

entries.name: Duplicate hygiene pipeline closes and locks stale reports
entries.description: The duplicate hygiene pipeline links the dedupe slash command, `auto-close-duplicates.ts`, the backfill workflow, and Statsig logging so nightly jobs, retrospectives, and manual sweeps all share one countdown policy with debug logs for each decision.

entries.name: Duplicate-comment backfill triggers dedupe workflow
entries.description: `scripts/backfill-duplicate-comments.ts` powers `.github/workflows/backfill-duplicate-comments.yml`, which exposes `days_back` and a `dry_run` input defaulting to true so maintainers can audit which issues would be retriggered before firing off workflow dispatches.

entries.name: Auto-close script labels duplicates and leaves canonical pointers
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` patches closed issues with `state_reason: duplicate`, applies the `duplicate` label, and posts a follow-up comment linking to the canonical issue number extracted from the dedupe bot's message. The human-readable note explains how to reopen if the closure was wrong, minimizing confusion when the workflow auto-resolves reports.

entries.name: Duplicate backfill script supports ranged replays with throttling
entries.description: `scripts/backfill-duplicate-comments.ts` pages issues in created-desc order and filters by `MIN_ISSUE_NUMBER`/`MAX_ISSUE_NUMBER`, logging when a page falls outside the window so operators know why the sweep stopped.

entries.name: Auto-close script centralises GitHub requests
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` defines `githubRequest` to set `Accept: application/vnd.github.v3+json`, attach a custom User-Agent, JSON-encode bodies, and throw on non-2xx responses so every call shares hardened error handling.

entries.name: Auto-close parser handles inline and URL references
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts`'s `extractDuplicateIssueNumber` first grabs `#123` tokens then matches full `github.com/<repo>/issues/<n>` URLs, preventing comment format drift from breaking auto-closing.

entries.name: Auto-close script defaults repository metadata
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` reads `GITHUB_REPOSITORY_OWNER`/`GITHUB_REPOSITORY_NAME` and falls back to `anthropics/claude-code`, letting maintainers run it locally while targeting this repo by default.

entries.name: Auto-close pagination caps API usage
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` requests 100 issues per page and breaks once `page > 20`, bounding API traversal if GitHub keeps returning results unexpectedly.

entries.name: Auto-close validates duplicate comment phrasing
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` only considers comments containing both "Found" and "possible duplicate" from Bot users, eliminating false positives before closing issues.

entries.name: Auto-close workflow schedules daily Bun task
entries.description: `.github/workflows/auto-close-duplicates.yml` runs daily at 09:00 UTC, offers a manual `workflow_dispatch`, installs Bun, and gives the job 10 minutes to execute `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` with repository owner/name env vars and optional `STATSIG_API_KEY`.

entries.name: Backfill script prints PAT usage guidance
entries.description: `scripts/backfill-duplicate-comments.ts` throws a multi-line usage message when `GITHUB_TOKEN` is absent, documenting required scopes and optional env vars before maintainers run the sweep.

entries.name: Backfill dispatch helper triggers dedupe workflow
entries.description: `scripts/backfill-duplicate-comments.ts` posts to `/actions/workflows/claude-dedupe-issues.yml/dispatches` with `ref: main` and `issue_number`, honouring dry-run mode before spawning dedupe comments retroactively.

entries.name: Backfill pagination limits issue ranges
entries.description: `scripts/backfill-duplicate-comments.ts` fetches issues in created-desc order and filters between configurable `MIN_ISSUE_NUMBER`/`MAX_ISSUE_NUMBER` (defaults 1/4050) before forcing a one-second pause between dispatches.

entries.name: Backfill workflow provisions Bun with Actions write
entries.description: `.github/workflows/backfill-duplicate-comments.yml` grants `actions: write`, installs the latest Bun runtime, and gives the job 30 minutes so the script can dispatch the dedupe workflow repeatedly without timing out.

entries.name: Backfill workflow exposes days_back input
entries.description: `.github/workflows/backfill-duplicate-comments.yml` offers a `days_back` choice (default 90) even though the Bun script consumes min/max issue numbers, documenting the operator-facing control that still needs mapping in the script.

entries.name: Gitattributes keeps Bun duplicate scripts portable
entries.description: `.gitattributes` guarantees LF endings globally, so the Bun-based `auto-close-duplicates.ts` and `backfill-duplicate-comments.ts` run the same inside GitHub Actions and the devcontainer without CRLF shebang bugs when the firewall script rebuilds volumes.

entries.name: Auto-close script inspects reactions before closing
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` calls `/issues/comments/{id}/reactions` for the latest duplicate-detection note and checks whether the original reporter left a `-1` reaction. If the author disagrees, the job skips the auto-close so only uncontested duplicates get sealed, matching the human escalation policy in `.claude/commands/dedupe.md`.

entries.name: Auto-close duplicate sweep emits granular debug telemetry
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` prefixes each stage with `[DEBUG]` logsâ€”pagination pages, candidate discovery, reaction lookups, skip reasonsâ€”and wraps outcomes in `[INFO]`/`[SUCCESS]` summaries. Workflow operators can trace exactly why an issue was skipped or closed without rerunning the script locally.

entries.name: Backfill script reports simulated and real dispatch totals
entries.description: `scripts/backfill-duplicate-comments.ts` logs `[DEBUG]` pagination progress, marks `[DRY RUN]` dispatches, and prints a closing summary with processed issues, duplicate-free candidates, and how many workflows would run versus actually triggered. The log stream doubles as an audit trail for retrospective sweeps.

entries.name: Backfill pagination halts once issue range is exhausted
entries.description: `scripts/backfill-duplicate-comments.ts` inspects the oldest issue on each fetched page and stops paginating once numbers drop below `MIN_ISSUE_NUMBER` or after 200 pages. The guard prevents runaway API scans when the requested window has already been traversed.

entries.name: Auto-close waits three days after the duplicate comment
entries.description: `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` skips candidates when the most recent dedupe comment is newer than the computed `threeDaysAgo` cutoff, preventing the nightly sweep from closing issues that were just marked as potential duplicates.

entries.name: Auto-close skips when activity resumes after the dedupe comment
entries.description: Before closing an issue, `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` scans for any comments posted after the dedupe bot message; if reporters or maintainers replied, the script logs the activity and leaves the thread open for humans to resolve.

entries.name: Auto-close duplicates workflow limits each run to ten minutes
entries.description: `auto-close-duplicates.yml` sets `timeout-minutes: 10`, bounding the nightly sweep and avoiding unbounded API retries.

entries.name: Backfill only dispatches dedupe runs for issues without prior bot comments
entries.description: `backfill-duplicate-comments.ts` skips issues that already contain a "Found possible duplicate" bot message, avoiding duplicate countdown threads.

entries.name: Security guidance plugin registers pre-tool reminder hook
entries.description: `plugins/security-guidance/.claude-plugin/plugin.json` publishes version 1.0.0 of the security reminder with security-category metadata and David Dworken as author, while `hooks/hooks.json` wires a PreToolUse command through `${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT}` so the Python hook resolves no matter where the bundle is installed and matches `Edit|Write|MultiEdit` tools to guarantee every file-editing invocation hits the reminder before it runs.

entries.name: Security guidance plugin bundles hooks and reminder logic
entries.description: The security-guidance bundle keeps the manifest, hooks config, and Python warning engine together so a marketplace install ships enforcement ready. The manifest description explicitly calls out command injection, XSS, and unsafe code pattern coverage, while `hooks.json` invokes `security_reminder_hook.py` from `${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT}` to deliver that guidance without extra wiring.

entries.name: Devcontainer grants NET_ADMIN/NET_RAW and waits for firewall
