entries.description: `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` adds `--cap-add=NET_ADMIN` and `--cap-add=NET_RAW` so `init-firewall.sh` can flush iptables and manage ipsets, sets `postStartCommand` to `sudo /usr/local/bin/init-firewall.sh`, and keeps VS Code detached with `waitFor: postStartCommand` so the elevated capabilities are exercised only by the firewall script before developers connect.

entries.name: Security reminder enumerates high-risk patterns
entries.description: `projects/claude-code/plugins/security-guidance/hooks/security_reminder_hook.py` defines nine rule blocks covering GitHub Actions templating, child_process.exec, eval/new Function, React XSS sinks (`dangerouslySetInnerHTML`, `innerHTML`, `document.write`), and Python pickle/os.system usage, including a GitHub Actions rule that lists the dozen high-risk `github.event.*` fields to treat as tainted input. When a matcher hits the Edit payload the hook surfaces the ruleâ€™s guidance so maintainers know which safer alternative to adopt before rerunning the command.

entries.name: Firewall allowlist restricts egress to vetted services
entries.description: `.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` rebuilds iptables from scratch, creates an `allowed-domains` ipset, and adds GitHub web/api/git CIDRs (compressed with `aggregate`) plus resolved IPs for registry.npmjs.org, api.anthropic.com, sentry.io, statsig.anthropic.com, statsig.com, marketplace.visualstudio.com, vscode.blob.core.windows.net, and update.code.visualstudio.com. Each resolved address is validated against a strict IPv4 regex before `ipset add`, so the allowlist never accepts malformed DNS answers.

entries.name: Firewall script validates GitHub metadata before allowlisting
entries.description: `.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` fetches `https://api.github.com/meta`, bails out immediately if the payload is empty, refuses to continue if the JSON lacks `.web`, `.api`, or `.git`, and rejects any CIDR that fails a strict IPv4 regex before adding it to `allowed-domains`. Those checks stop the firewall from booting with a partial or malformed GitHub allowlist when the API or tooling misbehaves.

entries.name: Firewall only admits DNS-verified egress domains
entries.description: The resolution loop in `.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` uses `dig +noall +answer A` to collect IPv4 records for every curated domain, streams them through `while read -r ip` so each address is added individually, rejects any value that fails the IPv4 regex, and aborts if a host returns no A records. Only validated IPs get added to the `allowed-domains` ipset, keeping outbound traffic constrained to intended services.

entries.name: Firewall script preserves DNS, SSH, and localhost traffic
entries.description: Before tightening policies, `.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` whitelists UDP/TCP port 53 for DNS with both OUTPUT and INPUT rules, permits outbound SSH (with a matching INPUT rule for established responses), and opens loopback interfaces. Those allowances keep package installs, git fetches via SSH, and local tooling running even after default DROP rules are applied.

entries.name: Firewall script hardens shell options
entries.description:
`.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` starts with `set -euo pipefail` and `IFS=$'
	'`, preventing globbing surprises, catching curl/jq pipeline failures, and avoiding whitespace splits when replaying iptables commands via `xargs` before rewriting iptables.

entries.name: Firewall restores Docker DNS chains
entries.description: `.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` captures existing Docker NAT rules via `iptables-save`, creates `DOCKER_OUTPUT`/`DOCKER_POSTROUTING` with `-N ... || true` so first boots do not fail, and replays the saved lines so container DNS still works after the flush.

entries.name: Security reminder merges MultiEdit content
entries.description: `security_reminder_hook.py` assembles `MultiEdit` payloads by concatenating `edits[*].new_string` with spaces via `extract_content_from_input`, and falls back to `new_string`/`content` for Edit/Write tools so pattern scans cover every edit chunk before enforcement.

entries.name: Security reminder steers exec usage to execFileNoThrow
entries.description: `security_reminder_hook.py`'s `child_process_exec` rule not only warns on `child_process.exec`/`execSync` but includes a sample `execFileNoThrow` import and call, plus bullet points about Windows compatibility, structured output, and error handling, steering developers toward the helper as the sanctioned alternative.

entries.name: Firewall retains access to the host LAN subnet
entries.description: `.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` derives the host gateway with `ip route`, rewrites it to a `/24` network via `sed`, and adds matching INPUT/OUTPUT ACCEPT rules so the container can still reach services on the developerâ€™s LAN while other destinations remain blocked.

entries.name: Firewall purges stale allowed-domains ipset before rebuild
entries.description: `.devcontainer/init-firewall.sh` calls `ipset destroy allowed-domains 2>/dev/null || true` before recreating the allowlist so leftover entries from previous boots cannot persist into the new policy.

entries.name: Firewall ipset stores both CIDRs and single IPs
entries.description: The script uses `ipset create allowed-domains hash:net`, letting the same set accept GitHub CIDR ranges and individual IPv4 addresses resolved from approved domains.

entries.name: Firewall aborts when DNS answers are missing or malformed
entries.description: For each curated domain, the script exits with an error if `dig` returns no A records or if a record fails the IPv4 regex, preventing empty or tainted entries from entering `allowed-domains`.

entries.name: Firewall sets INPUT, OUTPUT, and FORWARD defaults to DROP
entries.description: `init-firewall.sh` resets the policies for INPUT, OUTPUT, and FORWARD to DROP, then selectively re-opens established flows and ipset-approved destinations so no legacy ACCEPT policies survive the reset.

entries.name: Firewall only permits outbound traffic to the allowed-domains set
entries.description: After rebuilding the ipset, the script appends `iptables -A OUTPUT -m set --match-set allowed-domains dst -j ACCEPT`, making ipset membership the sole criterion for egress.

entries.name: Firewall re-authorizes established connections after tightening policies
entries.description: Once default DROP policies are set, the script restores bidirectional access for `ESTABLISHED,RELATED` traffic so legitimate replies continue without reopening broad ports.

entries.name: Firewall self-test uses curl timeouts to prove block and allow paths
entries.description: The script finishes by running `curl --connect-timeout 5` against https://example.com (expecting failure) and https://api.github.com (expecting success) to verify the allowlist without hanging the container.

entries.name: Security reminder probabilistically prunes stale suppression files
entries.description: `security_reminder_hook.py` runs a 10% cleanup pass that deletes `security_warnings_state_*.json` files older than 30 days, keeping the per-session suppression cache from growing without bound.

entries.name: Security reminder can be disabled via ENABLE_SECURITY_REMINDER=0
entries.description: Setting `ENABLE_SECURITY_REMINDER=0` makes the hook exit early, giving operators an explicit override while keeping enforcement on by default.

entries.name: Code architect agent runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/agents/code-architect.md` pins the architect agent to sonnet, paints it green, and grants heavy-weight exploration tools (Glob, Grep, LS, Read, NotebookRead) plus orchestration helpers (WebFetch, WebSearch, TodoWrite, KillShell, BashOutput) so blueprint runs can sweep the repo and queue follow-ups without losing context, while the prompt demands the final plan enumerate patterns with file:line, the chosen architectural decision, component responsibilities, data flow, and phased build sequence.

entries.name: Code explorer agent runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/agents/code-explorer.md` keeps the explorer on sonnet, marks it yellow, and equips the same filesystem and research toolkit (Glob, Grep, LS, Read, NotebookRead, WebFetch, WebSearch, TodoWrite, KillShell, BashOutput) so discovery passes can trace call chains while recording todos, and the instructions insist the report list entry points, step-by-step execution flow, dependencies, architecture layers, and essential files with precise references.

entries.name: Feature dev reviewer runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/agents/code-reviewer.md` runs the reviewer on sonnet with a red avatar and the repo-sweeping tool palette, aligning architecture and review phases around identical capabilities, and it explicitly filters for confidence â‰¥80 issues grouped as Critical vs Important with file/line, CLAUDE.md citations, and fix suggestions.

entries.name: PR toolkit reviewer runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/code-reviewer.md` switches the PR reviewer to opus with a green badge and omits a `tools:` block, signalling that higher-capacity reasoning drives reviews while relying on Claude's default command set, and the prompt directs agents to trigger after each coding chunk, review unstaged diffs by default, and report only â‰¥80 confidence findings tied to guidelines.

entries.name: Comment analyzer runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/comment-analyzer.md` keeps the agent on an inherited model with a green avatar and no explicit tool list, documenting that comment health checks lean on default Read/WebFetch skills, and it forces outputs structured as Summary, Critical Issues, Improvement Opportunities, Recommended Removals, and Positive Findings with file:line evidence.

entries.name: PR test analyzer runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/pr-test-analyzer.md` inherits its model, sets the avatar cyan, and relies on the default tool stack, capturing that behavioural test scoring is prompt-driven, and the rubric rates gaps 1â€“10 while requiring sections for Summary, Critical Gaps, Important Improvements, Test Quality Issues, and Positive Observations with concrete regression examples.

entries.name: Silent failure hunter runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/silent-failure-hunter.md` keeps the inherited model, colours the agent yellow, and documents no custom tool list, emphasising that error-hunting relies on the prompt's auditing rules, which mandate severity tiers (CRITICAL/HIGH/MEDIUM), hidden-error enumerations, user impact notes, and sample fix snippets for each finding.

entries.name: Type design analyzer runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/type-design-analyzer.md` inherits its model and sets a pink avatar without defining tools, clarifying that invariant scoring depends purely on prompt guidance that captures a per-type invariant list plus four 1â€“10 ratings (encapsulation, invariant expression, usefulness, enforcement) with strengths, concerns, and improvements.

entries.name: Code simplifier runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/agents/code-simplifier.md` moves simplification work to opus without specifying tools, recording that the higher-tier model handles rewrites while the default command set remains available, and the playbook stresses preserving behaviour, applying CLAUDE.md standards (e.g., avoid nested ternaries, prefer function declarations), and focusing only on recently touched code.

entries.name: Agent SDK TypeScript verifier runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/agent-sdk-dev/agents/agent-sdk-verifier-ts.md` fixes the TypeScript verifier on sonnet with no explicit tool overrides, signalling that SDK audits depend on the prompt's checklist while default commands suffice, and that checklist covers package.json ES-module flags, tsconfig sanity, running `npx tsc --noEmit`, `.env.example` hygiene, and a PASS / PASS WITH WARNINGS / FAIL status block with recommendations.

entries.name: Agent SDK Python verifier runtime profile
entries.description: `plugins/agent-sdk-dev/agents/agent-sdk-verifier-py.md` mirrors the TypeScript setupâ€”sonnet model, no extra toolsâ€”documenting that Python SDK checks share the same runtime expectations while cross-checking requirements/pyproject, Python version, `.env` handling, and issuing PASS / PASS WITH WARNINGS / FAIL reports against the official SDK doc patterns.

entries.name: TS verifier checks package module mode and Node engines
entries.description: The TypeScript verifier walks package.json looking for `"type": "module"` and a compatible Node.js `engines` range, treating mismatched module formats or stale runtimes as correctness issues before any SDK code runs.

entries.name: TS verifier validates build/start/typecheck scripts
entries.description: Its checklist inspects package.json for `build`, `start`, and `typecheck` entries, making sure the generated project exposes runnable scripts that exercise the SDK instead of leaving tooling glue up to the user.

entries.name: TS verifier cross-checks builds against official docs
entries.description: Before scoring an app, the TypeScript verifier explicitly WebFetches https://docs.claude.com/en/api/agent-sdk/typescript and compares code against the documented patterns, flagging deviations rather than relying on local heuristics.

entries.name: TS verifier report breaks down criticals, warnings, passes
entries.description: Its required output begins with an Overall Status (PASS / PASS WITH WARNINGS / FAIL) then enumerates Critical Issues, Warnings, Passed Checks, and Recommendations, forcing structured audits instead of ad-hoc prose.

entries.name: Python verifier insists on documented virtual-env setup
entries.description: The Python prompt looks for README guidance around virtual environments and setup steps, treating missing instructions as a warning so developers know how to recreate the runtime safely.

entries.name: Python verifier audits requirements and reproducibility
entries.description: It scans requirements.txt or pyproject.toml for the `claude-agent-sdk` pin and supporting deps, ensuring version constraints and dependency lists are complete so another operator can recreate the environment.

entries.name: Python verifier validates flows against SDK reference
entries.description: The Python verifier also WebFetches https://docs.claude.com/en/api/agent-sdk/python and compares the appâ€™s agent initialization, permissions, and session handling to the official examples before rendering a verdict.

entries.name: SDK verifiers enforce .env.example and gitignore hygiene
entries.description: Both verifier prompts demand an `.env.example` with `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` plus `.env` in `.gitignore`, flagging any hardcoded secrets or missing templates as security failures.

entries.name: Code architect agent follows analyzeâ†’designâ†’blueprint ritual
entries.description: `code-architect.md` spells out a three-stage loopâ€”extract patterns and CLAUDE.md guidance, design the architecture decisively, then deliver an implementation blueprint with files, data flow, and phased build stepsâ€”so the runtime keeps planning grounded in real code before work begins.

entries.name: Code explorer maps entry points, flows, layers, and strengths
entries.description: The `code-explorer.md` runtime walks discovery through entry-point hunting, call-chain tracing, architecture layer mapping, and implementation detail capture, then expects the report to list dependencies, strengths, issues, and the essential files newcomers must read.

entries.name: Comment analyzer tests accuracy, completeness, and long-term value
entries.description: `comment-analyzer.md` forces the agent to cross-check every claim against code, ensure comments capture assumptions and edge cases, and flag lines that merely restate code, keeping documentation focused on durable rationale.

entries.name: PR test analyzer rates gaps on a 1â€“10 criticality scale
entries.description: The test analyzer prompt scores missing coverage from 1â€“10, reserving 9â€“10 for regressions that could take prod down and 7â€“8 for major business flows, so reviewers can triage which tests must ship before merge.

entries.name: Silent failure hunter demands logError/logForDebugging coverage
entries.description: `silent-failure-hunter.md` insists every catch block surface context via the project loggers (logForDebugging, logError, logEvent) and lists which hidden exceptions a broad catch might swallow, making error handling reviews concrete.

entries.name: Code simplifier favors explicit patterns over clever tricks
entries.description: `code-simplifier.md` reiterates CLAUDE.md rules like preferring function declarations, banning nested ternaries, and keeping refinements scoped to the fresh diff so the agent can clean up code without introducing clever regressions.

entries.name: Dedupe command locks ToolUse to GitHub CLI
entries.description: `.claude/commands/dedupe.md` only permits GitHub CLI subcommands (`gh issue view`, `gh issue list`, `gh search`, `gh api`, `gh issue comment`), directs Claude to launch five parallel `gh search` agents with diverse keywords, and forbids other tools so manual sweeps mirror `auto-close-duplicates.ts` before posting the standard countdown comment.

entries.name: Commit+push+PR command enforces git/gh sequence
entries.description: `.claude/commands/commit-push-pr.md` allowlists only `git checkout --branch`, `git add`, `git status`, `git commit`, `git push`, and `gh pr create`, bundling branch creation, commit, push, and PR creation into one ToolUse so the entire sequence stays atomic and scriptable.

entries.name: Commit command limits edits to staging primitives
entries.description: `plugins/commit-commands/commands/commit.md` exposes only `git status`, `git diff`, `git add`, and `git commit`, and preloads branch name plus a `git log --oneline -10` preview so Claude can stage and commit in one response without touching the shell outside those commands.

entries.name: Review PR command restricts tooling to Bash/Glob/Grep/Read/Task
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/commands/review-pr.md` restricts ToolUse to `Bash`, `Glob`, `Grep`, `Read`, and `Task`, letting Claude inspect diffs and queue specialist agents (tests, errors, comments, types, simplification) without arbitrary shelling or writes while it orchestrates the review workflow.

entries.name: Dedupe command enforces standard duplicate comment copy
entries.description: `.claude/commands/dedupe.md` ships a fixed reply that lists up to three linked duplicates, warns the issue will auto-close in three days, and instructs reporters to close their copy and ðŸ‘ the canonical issue or ðŸ‘Ž the bot comment if itâ€™s wrongâ€”the same signal `auto-close-duplicates.ts` watches before closing.

entries.name: Dedupe guardrails mirror automation workflow contracts
entries.description: `.claude/commands/dedupe.md`, `.github/workflows/claude-dedupe-issues.yml`, and `scripts/auto-close-duplicates.ts` now share the same gh-only tool allowlist, countdown wording, and thumbs-down escape hatch, and they log to Statsig with the same event nameâ€”keeping manual triage, nightly closures, and telemetry in lockstep.

entries.name: Clean gone command scripts safe branch cleanup sequence
entries.description: `plugins/commit-commands/commands/clean_gone.md` lists branches (`git branch -v`), records worktrees, then pipes `[gone]` branches through `sed`/`awk` to remove leading `+` before force-removing any matching worktree and deleting the branch. The echoed loop keeps the cleanup auditable and scoped to truly orphaned branches.

entries.name: Commit+push+PR command requires one atomic ToolUse bundle
entries.description: `.claude/commands/commit-push-pr.md` preloads status, diff, and branch context then walks the agent through five numbered stepsâ€”create a branch if still on main, make a single commit, push, open a PRâ€”and insists they all happen in one response with no extra chatter.

entries.name: Dedupe command forces todo-first multi-agent workflow
entries.description: `.claude/commands/dedupe.md` opens with a TODO list requirement, then mandates the sequence of agentsâ€”summary, five diverse searches, false-positive filterâ€”before it will allow posting the duplicate comment, keeping the hunt disciplined and auditable.

entries.name: Feature dev ritual pauses implementation until user approves
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/commands/feature-dev.md` walks through seven named phases and halts at the architecture gateâ€”Phase 5 explicitly says â€œDO NOT START WITHOUT USER APPROVALâ€â€”so Claude must ask clarifying questions, compare architecture options, and secure sign-off before any implementation ToolUse fires.

entries.name: Dedupe command refuses to run on already-triaged threads
entries.description: Step one in `.claude/commands/dedupe.md` is to verify the issue is open, still needs dedupe, and lacks a prior bot comment; otherwise Claude must stop before spamming the thread.

entries.name: Dedupe command mandates five parallel gh searches
entries.description: The playbook instructs Claude to launch five `gh search` agents with different keyword strategies before filtering candidates, widening duplicate discovery coverage.

entries.name: Commit command forces one message staging and commit
entries.description: `commit.md` reminds Claude it can batch multiple tool calls, then immediately orders â€œStage and create the commit using a single messageâ€¦ Do not send any other text.â€ That guardrail stops incremental staging or narrative responses and keeps commits atomic.

entries.name: Clean gone loop skips the primary worktree
entries.description: Before calling `git worktree remove`, the clean_gone loop compares the candidate path against `$(git rev-parse --show-toplevel)` and only removes it when they differ. That conditional prevents the guardrail from ever detaching the main checkout while still clearing stray worktrees.

entries.name: Feature dev command enforces sequential discovery questions
entries.description: The `Gather Requirements` block in `feature-dev.md` spells out five scoped promptsâ€”language, project name, agent type, starting point, tooling choiceâ€”and bolds the instruction to ask them one at a time, waiting for each answer. That pacing prevents Claude from overwhelming users or skipping critical context before planning.

entries.name: Feature dev guardrails confirm tooling preferences
entries.description: Step 5 of `feature-dev.md` tells Claude to propose its planned toolchain, let the user veto choices like npm vs pnpm, and respect the answer. By locking tool selection to user confirmation, the command avoids surprise dependency managers or runners.

entries.name: Feature dev ritual mandates verifier agents per language
entries.description: In the Verification phase, `feature-dev.md` requires launching `agent-sdk-verifier-ts` for TypeScript or `agent-sdk-verifier-py` for Python and reviewing the PASS/WARN/FAIL summary before declaring work complete. The guardrail bakes quality checks into the command instead of treating verification as optional.

entries.name: Claude dedupe workflow orchestrates issue analysis and Statsig logging
entries.description: `.github/workflows/claude-dedupe-issues.yml` triggers on new issues and manual reruns (with a required `workflow_dispatch` input `issue_number`), feeds `/dedupe ${{ github.repository }}/issues/${{ github.event.issue.number || inputs.issue_number }}` into `anthropics/claude-code-base-action@beta`, restricts permissions to `contents: read` and `issues: write`, sets a 10-minute timeout, and injects `GH_TOKEN` through the multi-line `claude_env` block so the slash command can label in place before Statsig logging.

entries.name: Issue telemetry workflow logs Statsig events on open/close
entries.description: `.github/workflows/log-issue-events.yml` listens to issue open/close events, loads number, repo, title, author, and created_at into env vars, escapes the title, stamps `time` via `date +%s000`, and sends a single POST to `https://events.statsigapi.net/v1/log_event` with `Content-Type: application/json` and `statsig-api-key: $STATSIG_API_KEY`, keeping telemetry inside Statsig without broad GitHub scopes.

entries.name: Claude dedupe workflow builds Statsig payload
entries.description: The Statsig step in `.github/workflows/claude-dedupe-issues.yml` uses `jq -n` with `--arg` to capture repository, issue number (cast with `| tonumber`), and `triggered_by`, includes `value: 1`, `time: (now | floor | tostring)`, and appends `workflow_run_id: "${{ github.run_id }}"` so analysts can correlate dedupe comments back to specific Actions runs.

entries.name: Claude dedupe workflow passes GH token via claude_env
entries.description: The dedupe actionâ€™s multi-line `claude_env` pins `GH_TOKEN=${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}` alongside the Anthropics key, avoiding shell quoting issues and ensuring both the slash command and the follow-up Statsig step inherit the authenticated token without baking credentials into prompts or scripts.

entries.name: Claude dedupe logs Statsig even on failure
entries.description: `.github/workflows/claude-dedupe-issues.yml` skips Statsig logging when `STATSIG_API_KEY` is unset by printing `STATSIG_API_KEY not found, skipping Statsig logging` and exiting 0, but otherwise runs the call under `if: always()` and reports whether the API returned HTTP 200/202, keeping telemetry failures visible even when the dedupe run itself errored.

entries.name: Statsig ties dedupe automation to command guardrails
entries.description: Statsig events named `github_duplicate_comment_added` carry the `triggered_by` field from `.github/workflows/claude-dedupe-issues.yml`, letting maintainers prove whether manual `/dedupe`, nightly auto-closes, or retro sweeps fired the comment while `log-issue-events.yml` records the corresponding issue metadata, keeping thumbs-down guardrails aligned with telemetry.

entries.name: Issue event logger parses Statsig HTTP status
entries.description: Where `log-issue-events.yml` fires a primitive POST, the dedupe workflow wraps `curl` with `-s -w "\n%{http_code}"` and splits the output so Statsig failures surface in logs; together they show how lightweight telemetry and fully-audited dedupe runs coexist in the same Statsig project.

entries.name: Issue telemetry workflow escapes titles to prevent injection
entries.description: Before sending JSON, `.github/workflows/log-issue-events.yml` runs `sed "s/"/\\"/g"` on `ISSUE_TITLE`, ensuring double quotes are escaped inside the heredoc payload so Statsig receives valid JSON even when issues contain quotes.

entries.name: Dedupe Statsig logger parses HTTP response for operators
entries.description: After logging, the dedupe workflow tails the combined curl output, separating body and status with `HTTP_CODE=$(echo "$RESPONSE" | tail -n1)` and `BODY=$(echo "$RESPONSE" | head -n-1)`, treating HTTP 200/202 as success and printing failures inline so support staff get a readable audit of Statsig responses.

entries.name: Issue telemetry workflow runs with read-only issue scope
entries.description: `log-issue-events.yml` grants the job only `issues: read`, demonstrating that Statsig logging operates without repository write access.

entries.name: Issue telemetry emits a github_issue_created Statsig event
entries.description: The curl payload posts `eventName: "github_issue_created"`, giving analysts a consistent signal whenever the workflow runs.

entries.name: Issue telemetry converts timestamps to milliseconds for Statsig
entries.description: Using `$(date +%s)000` ensures Statsig receives Unix epoch milliseconds, matching its API expectations.

entries.name: Issue telemetry populates metadata via environment variables
entries.description: The workflow copies issue fields into env vars and notes that no inline templating is used, reducing the risk of shell injection from user-supplied titles.

entries.name: Issue telemetry records number, repository, title, author, and created_at
entries.description: Those fields are bundled into the Statsig `metadata` object so analysts can group events without additional GitHub lookups.

entries.name: Statsig logger runs on both opened and closed issue events
entries.description: The `on:` block subscribes to `issues` `opened` and `closed`, so telemetry captures both creation and closure.

entries.name: Issue telemetry authenticates to Statsig with explicit API headers
entries.description: The curl call in `log-issue-events.yml` sets `Content-Type: application/json` and `statsig-api-key: $STATSIG_API_KEY`, keeping credentials in GitHub secrets while satisfying Statsig authentication.

entries.name: Claude dedupe workflow reuses Statsig headers for duplicate comment logging
entries.description: The Statsig step in `claude-dedupe-issues.yml` posts with the same `Content-Type` and `STATSIG-API-KEY` headers, aligning manual and automated dedupe telemetry with the issue logger.

entries.name: Feature dev command enforces architecture-first disciplines
entries.description: `plugins/feature-dev/commands/feature-dev.md` opens by mandating clarifying questions, deep code reading before edits, capturing every phase in TodoWrite, and prioritising simple, elegant solutions so the seven-phase ritual anchors on shared context before any implementation work starts.

entries.name: Discovery phase builds shared understanding before work begins
entries.description: Phase 1 of `feature-dev.md` tells Claude to create a todo list spanning all phases, interrogate the user about the problem, desired behaviour, and constraints when unclear, then echo back its understanding for confirmation before moving on.

entries.name: Exploration phase fan-outs multiple code explorer agents
entries.description: Phase 2 launches two or three code-explorer agents in parallel, each chasing a different angle (similar features, architecture maps, UI patterns) using the sample prompts baked into `feature-dev.md` so discovery covers abstractions, flow of control, and user experience simultaneously.

entries.name: Exploration phase requires reading agent-suggested files
entries.description: After explorer agents return, `feature-dev.md` orders Claude to read every file they list, synthesise the patterns it observed, and present a comprehensive summary before any design discussion, ensuring architectural decisions are grounded in concrete code references.

entries.name: Clarifying phase is flagged as critical and cannot be skipped
entries.description: Phase 3 is labelled CRITICAL inside `feature-dev.md`: Claude must review findings, enumerate every ambiguity (edge cases, integrations, scope, performance), post the full question list to the user, and wait for answers before designing anything.

entries.name: Clarifying phase handles "whatever you think" with explicit approval
entries.description: If the user defers with "whatever you think is best", the command instructs Claude to state its recommendation and secure explicit confirmation, preventing silent assumptions from leaking into architecture decisions.

entries.name: Architecture phase commissions divergent architect agents
entries.description: Phase 4 pushes Claude to launch two or three code-architect agents with competing lensesâ€”minimal change, clean architecture, pragmatic balanceâ€”so it can compare trade-offs before advocating a path forward.

entries.name: Architecture phase demands recommendation and user choice
entries.description: The command has Claude weigh each architect proposal, document trade-offs, and present a recommended approach with rationale while explicitly asking the user to choose, cementing shared ownership of the plan.

entries.name: Implementation phase is gated on explicit user approval
entries.description: Phase 5 begins with a bold DO NOT START directive: Claude must pause until the user authorises the chosen architecture, reinforcing that build work only follows after design sign-off.

entries.name: Implementation phase emphasises context review and todo hygiene
entries.description: Once cleared to build, `feature-dev.md` insists Claude reread all referenced files, honour established conventions, write clean well-documented code, and keep the TodoWrite plan updated so progress stays auditable.

entries.name: Quality review launches three specialised reviewer passes
entries.description: Phase 6 directs Claude to spin up three code-reviewer agents in parallel, each targeting simplicity, functional correctness, and convention alignment, delivering multi-angle scrutiny before handing findings to the user.

entries.name: Quality review loops the user into fix prioritisation
entries.description: After consolidating reviewer feedback, Claude must ask the user whether to fix issues now, later, or ship as-is and then act accordingly, keeping human owners in the decision loop.

entries.name: Summary phase documents outcomes and next steps
entries.description: Phase 7 closes the ritual by marking todos complete and summarising what changed, key decisions, touched files, and suggested follow-ups so handoffs stay traceable.

entries.name: Exploration phase supplies canned prompts for diverse sweeps
entries.description: The command includes ready-made prompts for explorer agentsâ€”finding similar features, mapping architecture, analysing implementations, or surfacing UI/testing patternsâ€”so operators can reuse proven queries without improvising.

entries.name: Review PR command begins by scoping review intent
entries.description: Step 1 of `review-pr.md` has Claude check git status, parse any aspect arguments, and decide whether to run a full sweep or a targeted subset before any agents spin up.

entries.name: Review PR command exposes aspect arguments for targeted checks
entries.description: The command lists the aspect keywords (comments, tests, errors, types, code, simplify, all) so operators can limit reviews to specific concerns instead of always dispatching the full toolkit.

entries.name: Diff discovery step pulls git file list and PR context
entries.description: Before picking agents, `review-pr.md` tells Claude to run `git diff --name-only` and `gh pr view` to understand which files changed and whether a PR already exists, anchoring scope decisions in actual diffs.

entries.name: Review PR command maps file types to specialised agents
entries.description: Step 4 encodes heuristics: run comment-analyzer for docs, pr-test-analyzer when tests change, silent-failure-hunter for error handling, type-design-analyzer for type updates, and defer code-simplifier until after issues pass, so automation stays relevant.

entries.name: Review PR supports sequential or parallel agent runs
entries.description: The workflow explains trade-offs: sequential runs ease comprehension, while the optional `parallel` argument launches everything at once for speed, letting operators tune throughput versus readability.

entries.name: Review PR aggregates agent findings into four buckets
entries.description: After agents finish, Claude must summarise critical issues, important issues, suggestions, and positive observations so fix triage separates must-dos from polish and highlights strengths.

entries.name: Review PR command ships a markdown action plan template
entries.description: Step 7 provides a formatted report skeleton with section headers, issue counts, and ordered recommendations so Claude can deliver consistent review outputs without ad-hoc formatting.

entries.name: Review PR documentation includes concrete usage examples
entries.description: `review-pr.md` illustrates default runs, aspect-filtered reviews, and the `parallel` option so users know the exact slash command syntax for common scenarios.

entries.name: Review PR tips encourage early runs and rechecks
entries.description: The tips section reminds operators to run reviews before opening PRs, focus on diffs, address critical issues first, and rerun reviews after fixes to ensure regressions are caught.

entries.name: Review PR outlines recommended points in the dev workflow
entries.description: Step-by-step guides cover using the command before commits, before PR creation, and after reviewer feedback so teams know when to trigger full or targeted sweeps.

entries.name: Review PR embeds a cheat sheet of agent specialties
entries.description: The command lists what each agent checks (comment accuracy, test gaps, silent failures, type invariants, general quality, simplification) so users remember why each tool matters without opening separate playbooks.

entries.name: Review PR defers code simplifier until after passing review
entries.description: The applicability table notes that code-simplifier should run only after other checks pass, framing it as a polish step rather than a bug-hunting tool.

entries.name: Review PR respects aspect arguments when selecting agents
entries.description: If arguments such as `tests errors` are supplied, the workflow limits agent launches to those aspects, preventing unnecessary analysis when operators request focused coverage.

entries.name: Review PR checks existing PR context via GitHub CLI
entries.description: By invoking `gh pr view`, Claude can incorporate PR metadata (like existing comments) into its review planning, aligning CLI runs with GitHub state.

entries.name: Review PR exposes a `parallel` flag for simultaneous agents
entries.description: Usage examples show appending `parallel` after `all` to launch every specialist concurrently, providing a documented escape hatch when speed outweighs step-by-step narration.

entries.name: Review PR auto-maps change types to specialist agents
entries.description: `plugins/pr-review-toolkit/commands/review-pr.md` always runs the general code reviewer, adds pr-test-analyzer for test files, comment-analyzer for documentation updates, silent-failure-hunter for error handling, type-design-analyzer for new types, and reserves code-simplifier for polish passes once reviews are clean.

entries.name: Review PR explains sequential and parallel execution trade-offs
entries.description: The workflow notes that sequential runs aid comprehension by producing one report at a time, while users can request a parallel sweep to launch every agent simultaneously when speed matters more than per-agent narration.

entries.name: Review PR aggregates findings into four severity buckets
entries.description: After all agents finish, the command expects Claude to group results into Critical Issues, Important Issues, Suggestions, and Positive Observations so teams can triage fixes while acknowledging strengths.

entries.name: Review PR provides a Markdown action plan template
entries.description: The command includes a ready-made summary template that lists counts per severity, annotates each issue with the responsible agent and file:line, highlights strengths, and ends with a numbered remediation plan.

entries.name: Review PR documents targeted invocation examples
entries.description: Examples in the command file show how to run the full toolkit, limit checks to tests and errors, or invoke a post-review â€œsimplifyâ€ pass, giving operators copy-pastable patterns for common scenarios.

entries.name: Review PR tips reinforce early, focused, iterative reviews
entries.description: The command reminds users to run reviews before opening a PR, focus agents on the diff, fix critical findings first, and re-run relevant agents after changes to confirm fixes took.

entries.name: Review PR defines before-commit, pre-PR, and post-feedback flows
entries.description: The workflow section suggests concrete sequencesâ€”such as running `review-pr code errors` before committing, `review-pr all` before opening the PR, and rerunning targeted agents after feedbackâ€”so teams can operationalise the slash command.

entries.name: Review PR enumerates supported aspect keywords
entries.description: The command documents the six aspect keywords (comments, tests, errors, types, code, simplify) plus `all`, clarifying how to target specific quality dimensions from the slash command arguments.

entries.name: New SDK app command starts with official doc review
entries.description: `new-sdk-app.md` has Claude WebFetch the overview plus language-specific SDK references and related guides (streaming, permissions, MCP, subagents, sessions) before planning, grounding advice in fresh documentation.

entries.name: New SDK app interviews the user in a fixed order
entries.description: The command asks language, project name, agent type, starting point, then tooling preferencesâ€”one question at a time, waiting for each responseâ€”to keep the scaffolding flow user-friendly and unambiguous.

entries.name: New SDK app provides agent type examples to prompt detail
entries.description: When asking about agent type, Claude offers categories like coding agents, business agents, and custom cases so users describe the intended workflow rather than giving vague answers.

entries.name: New SDK app lets users choose the project starting depth
entries.description: The starting-point question gives options ranging from minimal Hello World to feature-rich templates or a bespoke example, aligning scaffolding effort with user appetite.

entries.name: New SDK app confirms package manager preferences
entries.description: Before running installs, Claude must tell the user which tools it plans to use (npm vs pnpm/bun, pip vs poetry) and respect their choice, preventing surprises in local environments.

entries.name: Setup plan initialises project directories and manifests
entries.description: The plan covers creating the project folder, bootstrapping npm or Python packaging, and setting package.json to `type: module` for TypeScript projects before any SDK code appears.

entries.name: Setup plan adds language-specific configuration files
entries.description: Claude is told to author tsconfig.json with SDK-friendly settings for TypeScript, or complementary Python configs when needed, so scaffolds compile out of the box.

entries.name: Setup plan mandates checking the latest SDK versions
entries.description: Before installation, the command has Claude inspect npm or PyPI for current versions and tell the user what it will install, keeping projects pinned to up-to-date releases.

entries.name: Setup plan installs SDKs and verifies installed versions
entries.description: Claude installs `@anthropic-ai/claude-agent-sdk` or `claude-agent-sdk`, then confirms versions via package.json or `pip show` so the setup report documents exactly what landed.

entries.name: Setup plan scaffolds starter source files with examples
entries.description: The instructions call for creating TypeScript `index.ts` or Python `main.py` containing basic query examples and modern error handling so teams start from working code.

entries.name: Setup plan provisions environment templates safely
entries.description: Claude must create `.env.example` with `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`, ensure `.env` is gitignored, and explain how to obtain keys, baking security hygiene into the scaffold.

entries.name: Setup plan optionally seeds a `.claude` workspace
entries.description: The plan offers to create a `.claude/` directory hierarchy for agents and commands if the user wants deeper integration, making advanced setups a single prompt away.

entries.name: Implementation stage executes plan with version checks and verification
entries.description: During implementation, Claude is reminded to re-check package versions, install dependencies, create files, and build a working example before reporting success.

entries.name: Implementation mandates TypeScript builds pass `npx tsc --noEmit`
entries.description: For TypeScript projects, the command requires running `npx tsc --noEmit` and fixing every type error before declaring setup complete.

entries.name: Implementation double-checks Python imports and syntax
entries.description: Python scaffolds must validate imports and basic syntax, mirroring the TypeScript emphasis on compilation so both language paths ship runnable code.

entries.name: Implementation tailors the starter example to the chosen agent type
entries.description: Claude is told to craft a working example aligned with the user's agent type and annotate it with helpful comments, turning scaffolds into teachable templates.

entries.name: New SDK app immediately triggers language-specific verifier agents
entries.description: After scaffolding, the command launches `agent-sdk-verifier-ts` or `agent-sdk-verifier-py` to audit configuration, SDK usage, and readiness, then reviews the results for issues to fix.

entries.name: Verification report captures status, critical issues, warnings, and passes
entries.description: `new-sdk-app.md` prescribes the verifier output formatâ€”overall status, critical issues, warnings, passed checks, and recommendationsâ€”ensuring follow-up conversations stay structured.

entries.name: New SDK app closes with runnable next steps
entries.description: The getting-started guide instructs users to set API keys and run `npm start`/`node --loader ts-node` or `python main.py`, so they can immediately execute the scaffolded agent.

entries.name: New SDK app links back to language references and key concepts
entries.description: Claude provides direct links to TypeScript and Python SDK docs and recaps concepts like system prompts, permissions, tools, MCP, and subagents to accelerate onboarding.

entries.name: New SDK app suggests common follow-up enhancements
entries.description: Suggested next steps include customising system prompts, adding custom tools via MCP, configuring permissions, and building subagents, guiding users beyond the starter scaffold.

entries.name: Important notes reinforce latest versions and user preferences
entries.description: The command's notes remind Claude to always fetch the newest SDK releases, verify installed versions, check for existing files before creating them, respect preferred package managers, and keep the conversation interactive and educational.

entries.name: Important notes emphasise verifying code before claiming success
entries.description: Claude must not consider setup complete until type checks (for TS) or syntax checks (for Python) pass and verification agents report healthy status, preventing half-configured projects from shipping.

entries.name: New SDK app keeps the onboarding conversational
entries.description: The closing instructions reiterate asking one question per message and making the process educational, shaping the user experience as an interactive pairing session rather than a monologue.

entries.name: Dedupe command aborts on closed or feedback-only issues
entries.description: Step 1 of `.claude/commands/dedupe.md` has Claude confirm the issue still needs triageâ€”skipping closed threads, broad feedback, or issues it already commented onâ€”so duplicate sweeps don't spam maintainers.

entries.name: Dedupe command enforces the standard countdown comment
entries.description: The command includes the exact Markdown block the agent must postâ€”enumerating up to three duplicates, warning about auto-close in three days, and instructing users to close or ðŸ‘Žâ€”keeping responses consistent across manual and automated triage.

entries.name: Dedupe command mandates a todo list before searches
entries.description: The notes under `.claude/commands/dedupe.md` tell Claude to create a todo list up front so it can track each subtaskâ€”checks, summary, searches, filtering, commentâ€”before the multi-agent fanout begins.
